review_title: Stuck in their ways, very stagnant
pros: Health insurance and related benefits are pretty decent. There are quite a few good people who genuinely try their best to make things better at the company.
cons: Most if not all the teams utilize outdated hardware and software, with extremely slow turnaround time on fixing issues, updating software, deprecating EOL hardware/software, and overall lacking in drive to make things better. Management would rather pay for many outsourced unqualified contractors to act as technical support 24/7 than hire software engineers to develop solutions to their problems. Similarly, management would rather maintain legacy code from the early 2000's than to replace those projects with modern programming languages, frameworks, tools, and technologies. I also personally had a bad manager, who kept pushing for technologies that I believed should have been a much lower priority for us to move forward with compared to the exponentially rising technical debt that we were accruing. This manager also disrespected a coworker who was dealing with an immediate family member that was dying, telling them to prioritize work over their terminally ill relative.

job_title: Prescription Benefit Specialist in Houston, TX
pros: Decent priced Cigna insurance. Room for growth. Monthly bonuses based off metrics. Bonus structure based off your effort. Paid (most) holidays off. Nice superiors.
cons: No matter how great your “conversion” rate is, your Quality must be great or else you get no bonus. Some SMEs provide inaccurate info. Training classes don’t offer extra pay. No shift differential pay. No extra pay for speaking another language. Metrics include hold time while waiting for another dept (which can take a really long time).

pros: PTO hours and PST are the reason I stay, and its work at home. For now… also OT bonuses are offered if you hit X amount of hours of OT

review_title: Stay away from ESI and their site management!
pros: Actually the company might be better now because Cigna has taken over. Cigna looks like a good company. They hopefully are better to their employees than Express Scripts ever was.
cons:
There are so many I cannot mention them all here. If you worked for them before Cigna took over, it got really bad (degrading and just nasty) and unprofessional management! I am talking about management at the Albuquerque site. They had certain cliques, and were very good to those people, but horrible to the rest of us. They fired over 5 pharmacist’s when 
they, and the company, successfully got rid of the Union. They swore to our pharmacist’s they would take care of them, if they dumped the Union. Right before Cigna took over they got rid of any pharmacist’s that they did not like, or who had health problems, or whatever they could make up to make you look really bad so they could fire you. They told us we could not discuss our pay with anyone, because we found out some pharmacist’s were getting paid less money for doing the same jobs. 
I could go on and on. But, in conclusion please do not go to work for Express Scripts at the Albuquerque site!!! Other sites may have been better, I do not know about them. However, from what I have read about the other sites on Glassdoor, I don’t think that was true.

review_title: Not as exciting as it once was
pros: There are a lot of good, hard-working, down-to-earth people here. If you can find yourself in the right position on the right team, you'll have opportunities to work on a diverse set of projects in a fast-paced challenging environment with smart people. PTO is pretty good.
cons:
If you find yourself on the wrong team, you'll be managing tedious second-rate processes with limited impact and no real hope of making a significant difference. If you enjoy treading water you'll be fine, but if you get bored of the same thing every day you may not be happy. There are jobs like this at every company, but the size and growth of Express Scripts has made these positions much more prevalent than they used to be. It's much more likely to find yourself in one of these dead-end positions nowadays. 
It feels more crowded than it used to, and the roles are smaller and more focused on mind-bending levels of detail about really specific things. Actually getting meaningful things done has become very difficult as it requires weigh-in from countless people with their own highly specific needs. Decisions only get made at the VP level, and then often with politics and turf fallout. If you find yourself in a losing or forgotten piece of the organization, jump ship - trust me, you'll be sorry if you don't.

pros: None none none none none
cons: I worked as patient a care advocate, pharmacy technician and pharmacy technician in the call center. The training is very poor. You are micromanaged to the point of insanity. You are monitored constantly every moment and you are never commended on what you've done right. It's always the small things you get wrong. Even small things like forgetting ask for a insignificant detail you'll get fired if you do that 3 times. They required you do get your stats while get all necessary and redundant details but make sure you finish the call in 3 minutes. That's not possible you can't do both. They even went as far to have a new system added that tracks the tone of your voice how long it takes you to respond and so on. We aren't robots we're human beings. The box just kept getting smaller and smaller to the point you feel like mindless drone with the ridiculous rules they add. You're expected to log on early to start your shift but if you try and log off a minute of two sooner so you don't get stuck on a 20 minute call before your shift ends you get in trouble. Time off was impossible. You had to fight to the death there was never enough hours because of the high turn over rate. And holidays they claim you get them off but you have to work most of them because they don't have enough employees to cover themselves. Once the pandemic started we were sent to work home and I had no choice but to work at my apartment . I would get blamed if my power or internet would go out. Their server devices were garbage because they weren't big enough to handle people working at home and we got punished if those went down and wouldn't get paid/take PTO without permission to cover that. If you were sick you were made to feel guilty for taking time off and kept asking when you were going to comeback. If you needed to get up to go to the bathroom you would get in trouble for going over the 3 minutes allowed and were told to wait until lunch. I had a health problem where I needed to use the bathroom an even had a diagnosis and doctor's note but I was told they don't do medical accommodations. That is discrimination. Finally I quit. And 6 months later I'm doing great at my new job and they decide to rip me anew one one more times and say I owe over $400 for unused pto even though I was told that would be taken care of. you waited 6 months later to tell me. right before I'm about to buy a house and I get the letter The DAY before it's due. Please do yourselves a favor no matter how desperate you are do not work for this company.

job_title: Coverage Determination Specialist in Baltimore, MD
pros: It’s a job that pays money and provides decent PTO
cons:
They gave one salary and position in the offer letter and then called both a typo once I took the job. Wanted me to sign a new offer letter with a lower salary and position or they were gonna fire me.

They don’t treat their employees like people. 

No one in management knows anything and doesn’t know who would know anything. 

They don’t care about you at all, just the numbers they can show to their bosses. 

Everyone is pretty nasty and rude. Like, everyone. Don’t ask questions if you want an answer. Only ask questions if you want their original statement repeated with emphasis and no clarification. 

Lots of expectations of employees (metrics, etc.) but zero standards for themselves. 

Don’t send an email if you want a response. Send at least three emails if you want an answer for literally anything, including one where you resend your original email and another where you CC their boss. 

Don’t expect to advance unless you rely heavily on nepotism.

Expect to know everything you’re doing wrong but not what you’re doing right. 

Their systems and processes are outdated. 

Expect to be trained based on what you did wrong and not initial training.

review_title: Great company where technology is a competitive advantage
job_title: IT Senior Director in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
I joined the technology organization 2 months ago, here are my observations thus far: 
+ empowered employees at all levels who are encouraged to challenge the status quo
+ helping clients and patients are truly the focus of the company... a VERY noble mission
+ Alignment at the highest c-suite levels that technology and data is a major competitive advantage
+ little bureaucracy and an org structure that feels flat and like a community.   Every employee gets to hear and ask questions to the CIO every other week.  No ivory towers. 
+ a technologists dream: agile, CI/CD, TDD, cloud (PCF), big data/analytics, mobile and watch apps, hack-a-thons, collaborative workspaces.  This is the journey the organization is on. 
+ great culture: supporting charities and community service is important; fun at work with ping pong tables, adult coloring murals, March Madness viewing party. Casual dress code is also nice.
cons: - I've been here two months and can find very little cons.   The company has gone through a major cultural transformation over the last 2 years with new C-suite leadership.  I did read through the glass door reviews before I accepted my position and I can say that most of the reviews are based on the old culture.  I am very glad I joined the Express Scripts team.

pros: Work at home ability, great insurance benefits
cons: Favoritism in management means you won’t go anywhere unless you fake it to make it or get chummy with managers. If that jives with you great, if it doesn’t vibe with who you are they will use you to get projects and extra work done and you will get nothing in return.

pros: Great non-leadership co-workers within internal departments. Casual work attire, flexible work from home policy, decent benefits.
cons:
There's a high expectation to succeed with little or no guidance; you're just expected to hit the ground running. And then when you fall short of expectations, there's little that is actually done to coach you other than identify what you did wrong. It's a recipe to set individuals up for failure since we're left to our own devices when it comes to success and failures. 

There's been many leadership changes in the past few years, making it difficult balance expectations with towing the line and managing new expectations. The worst is how a new leader can come on board with the pretense of trying to get to know you and your role, only to find out that it's for the sheer purpose of divesting it to someone else. It's pretentious, dishonest, and deceiving. 

In terms of employee recognition, there's an award platform, but it is not often used. There are points that can be issued to redeem through a catalogue, but points are rarely issued especially by senior leadership. Pat on the back, and off you go.

The worst is that there is a false sense of value about mental health and stress management. There's kitchy arbitrary tools and advice given (e.g. take frequent short breaks), but when there are more serious issues around depression or personal situations, all you get is acknowledgement of the situation but no actual nor genuine attempts to work with you on finding middle ground so that you can continue to be effective at work while you manage your personal challenges.

review_title: Make it a job and not your career
pros: During training, everybody is friendly. Believe it or not, there are opportunities for career advancement outside of PCA. They are good at hiring within. Health benefits are exceptional. Now have the option to work from home. 401K
cons: They only care about production. Customers are generally nasty. Typically, they are called thru a robocall and then minute that a PCA receives the call, the first words out of the patients' mouth is, "You called me". There are times when a issue is resolved and the customer will receive another call. This is an efficiency issue.  If you are an empath, the nasty customers will TEAR you apart. Supervisors can be friendly but they only there to hawk you and make sure that you are not in aftercall. Fellow peers are condescending in nature. Some are quick to make assumptions before they gather the evidence.  Working in a high call volume environment, you will quickly learn that there are peers that you prefer to speak with over others. When you talk to the good peers, they are good and helpful. The worse of the worse act as if you are being an inconvenience to them. They can be lazy and combative. The majority of pharmacists act like speaking to a patient care advocate is beneath them. System issues can result in ruining the work experience. High call volumes can be stressful, especially when patient care advocates are asked to keep up with all of their emails as well as assist fellow peers who may seek assistance when they have an issue or do not understand a concept. Pay is relatively low when compared to competitors. Raise is more like a cost of living adjustment. No raise was given in 2021, just a meager bonus for $600. The other incentives that they provide are conditional and certain metrics have to be met. More money comes in the form of overtime, where they are quick to offer when it is available. Team leaders will drop what they are doing to ensure that overtime needs are met. Also in 2021, Cigna started to implement mandatory overtime.

review_title: Your mileage may vary (this one is a real review)
job_title: None Provided in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
It's a big company with very complex business, so you can learn a lot about the industry if you are willing to put in the effort.  While many people are indeed unhappy, if you find yourself in the right business units, like sales, marketing, clinical (non-call center rph positions), there are people who are fairly content.

The company is also making some effort to address employee dissatisfaction in meaningful ways, but it is still in its infancy and nothing has come to fruition yet.
cons:
Even though the merger was many years ago, integration is still in an unresolved state.  I suspect this will not get resolved for another 7-10 years.  Cultural clashes aside, the problems at hand are difficult to solve due to complexity of healthcare and PBM business in general.

And every day, things get more complex as the industry invents more products to shift around cost burden, resulting in further patchwork solutions.

Unfortunately, there is no one in the company that has understanding of the entire breadth and depth of the problems at hand.

Many smart people have already left the company due to stress, poor pay, unjust demotions / promotions, performance management, loss of confidence in leadership.  Staggering number of talented people simply walked away on their own in recent year.

The unresolved integration issue puts tremendous amount of burden on almost all employees including service reps, account management, sales rep, project managers, developers, product owners, alike.

review_title: Unrealistic Standards from an Out-of-Touch Company.
job_title: Data Entry Technician in Troy, NY
pros:
1.) A paycheck in exchange for work.
2.) Paid Time Off (after accumulating enough hours).
3.) Friendly colleagues and supervisors (for the most part). 
4.) Occasional free food at the office.
cons:
1.) Unrealistic expectations of human (not robot) employees. We are given a very high number of prescriptions to fill every hour in mail, fax, and electronic queues. However, we only receive credit for new prescription "shells" that we create, and not scripts we have to forward to other departments (which accounts for about 1/4 of the work we actually do).

2.) Quantity over quality. Throughout my training and first 90 days of employment, "patient quality" (error-free prescriptions) was stressed as more important than meeting the numbers. I managed to stay error-free throughout my training and first 90 days. However, during my 90-day review, I was told I had 30 days to speed up or else the company and I would "separate." (I am not a slow typist at all; the standards just seem impossible to meet.)

3.) The B.S. Corporate Image. We have meetings once per month to emphasize "success stories" about Express Scripts. Euphemistic language is consistently used in the most ridiculous way, in order to convey a positive image about their own out-of-touch bureaucratic ideals. "Opportunities" is used when an employee is falling behind, as in "missed opportunities." (Ex: You only filled 200 scripts yesterday, so there's a perfect opportunity for you.) 

4.) The pay. $11/hour. Nothing more to say about that.

job_title: Human Resources in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great mission, I really believe we're making a huge difference. It's great to help fight the high costs of healthcare and help people have better health outcomes. I've been with the company for over 5 years and it's like a different world today. We're large so our impact is broad and we have a lot of opportunities to grow and learn new things. The leadership team and the culture have changed dramatically in the past few years so it's a much better environment where people are want to work together and have fun. I've never seen an evolution like this and it's exciting to be part of it.
cons: It's a fast paced environment which some people don't like. You have to show up ready to go but I actually like that. Definitely not a place to kick back and put your feet up. However, it's a lot better than it used to be. The parking lot gets pretty empty shortly after 5:00 so it's definitely not like the reputation from a few years ago. While the changes are real, it does take a long time to turn a company this large so not all leaders have caught up with the culture changes, and employees are still careful about trusting leaders.

review_title: Look elsewhere if in IT field
job_title: IT Department Employee in Bloomington, MN
pros: Average benefits, work space/building is clean and comfortable.  Cafeteria services are fine. Other than that pretty average company to work for is most regards.
cons:
This company is slowly laying off all it's workers at some of its worksites.  In late November 2010 about 200 IT workers were laid off and are being replaced with contractors or consultants mostly in Bloomington and St.Louis locations.  Other positions in the company seem to be out-sourced or off-shored - it's pretty sad.  They just announced they are closing the Bensalem PA location with 1,000 people being let go.

The IT area is being mainly affected by this, morale is poor, many people who are not laid off are looking for new jobs elsewhere.  Company seems to be looking to cut costs and save money where they can while making record profits.  

It seems the Bloomington MN location is slowly being closed down little by little and jobs shifted to the St. Louis headquarters - they would never admit to this but it appears that is what is happening. They are already advising that some of the floors in the Bloomington location will be leased out to other companies as they don't need the full building any longer for express scripts employees. Benefits that cost the company nothing have been taken away - such as casual work attire on Fridays.

Use to be a good company to work for but it has changed for the worse.

Employee benefits are just average - nothing special.

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The pro was that the job was only a 10 minute drive from my home and didn't require me to use the highway.  My coworkers were fine, many of them in their mid 20's and beginning to get immersed in the work world.
cons: Worked in the call center with patient assistance program for Pfizer medications.  There was no work/life balance. If you weren't able to be at work when you were scheduled and the absence was not planned in advance, you were penalized by receiving points on the discipline system.  The  St. Louis area had a blizzard in February of 2011 and I missed two days and was penalized.  The points you build up remain on your record for one year! There were no opportunities for advancement, supervisors  were unable to provide consistent leadership.  You could do the best job possible everyday and it accounts for nothing. you are constantly told that you are not doing what is needed, but what is needed is always changing!  I took the job to get my foot in the door at the company and found out it is basically impossible to obtain a position in the Pharmacy Benefit Management side of the company.  When I received a raise it was only .10 per hour.  My final payrate was 11.10 per hour. Not a living wage.  As a whole, my experience with the company was horrible.  We made no money but th CEO is raking in money.  Horrible.

pros: Even a bad Job is better than no job in this economy.
cons:
This place favors Nepotism and honestly, it might be more heavily associated with the Medco side of things.

We see jobs created for people who are failing at their present positions and this happens because, those employees are related to others or they know somebody high up in the company.  There's also been times when jobs were created for people two and three times over the course of two years just to give certain favorites more money that they didn't deserve.

All this Nepotism has created Anxiety for those hoping to get a fair shake and yet they're trapped under a relative of one of the management staff who couldn't even do the job they are doing but, was promoted to save the relatives job.  

Meanwhile, these managers take 3 and 4 hour off-site (not client related) lunches at times and if they need time off they get it and never seem to have to answer to anyone for their actions.  

However, since the Express-Scripts merger things have gotten slightly more fair, now it isn't just the people the Management manipulated that have anxiety, it is the Managers themselves as well but, their tyrannical nature has only come to the surface through all of this as they put more pressure on those that they used to protect.

pros: Healthcare companies like Express are on the leading edge to help manage costs for employers and health plans and improve health outcomes for patients.  How can that not make one feel good?
cons: The CEO is surrounded by leaders who are culture killers.  I truly believe he wants to improve the work environment and there have been some changes but he will not be able to create the culture he envisions.  Every leader who understood how to build a culture (usually legacy Medco) has been let go.  Employee engagement can't be very important if the most competent and capable leaders who knew how to deliver results and engage employees were not valued by the current leaders.  Tim is out of the loop on these things which is unfortunate.  There isn't enough goodwill built up so when the current leadership screws things up culturally the feeling is "here we go again" instead of giving them the benefit of the doubt.

job_title: Sales Advisor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Opportunity for growth and to work in different roles
cons: Huge company since merger w/ Cigna

pros:
Great hours - ability to work 40 hours Monday to Friday which is rare in pharmacy world
Great benefits and great 401K matching which is one of the highest in the industry
Employees start with 4 weeks of vacation per year which is significantly higher than industry standard
Merit based evaluations so if you work hard you get rewarded more than those who don't work as hard
Tech pay is higher than other pharmacy companies
Pharmacist pay is lower but work-life balance, benefits, and PTO make up for it
Pharmacist retention rates are extraordinary and I have not heard of a single pharmacist leave because they didn't like the job
I know tech attrition rate is high but I don't know why
cons: Company believes in constant change and changing while change is occurring which leads to stress for employees. Company needs to choose the direction for the year and stick to it and not change things on a daily basis (new policies, new SOPs, new rules, new guidelines, new contacts, new goals, new metrics happen alllllll the time). As soon as a goal is met, the bar is raised higher. If we as a team work extremely hard to meet the goal, management thinks it was a breeze so they raise next months goal.

review_title: Decent Benefits, Stressful, hostile work environment.
job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: Union Job at my site, because of this we are have a 90/10 insurance plan instead of ESI's default 70/30 plan.  Started at 15$hour and make 19$/hour now after 5 years, again I'd thank the union as most ESI Sites start at 10 or 12.
cons:
This is a thankless job.  The metric for keeping your job is your rate.  Quality has no recorded metric, I've never heard of anyone here getting fired for quality.  Back to rate - the only thing that matters is the rate number, did I mention you get credit for either processing the prescription or completely unclearing the whole thing?  They call this Defer'ing work which again they dont track and can only be recognized when another employee sees your work and takes the time to Email their supervisor, which doesn't happen, because it slows their rate down.

I actually liked the Job when it was Medco.  We had quality meetings bi-monthly where we discussed issues, we had prepared meals a few times per year, our birthdays were recognized, our annual Hire date was recognized with a small party with treats, we had bonuses, we received a gift card for christmas, etc.  All these things are gone.

Did I mention we have a 3 year pay freeze?

pros: Pay and bonuses. Monthly bonuses upwards of $300 before taxes. Good pay. Opportunities for voluntary time off if work flow is slow and overtime during periods of ramp up.
cons: Management is biased. In order to move up, you have to kiss some rears and not fight the system. Any form of individuality is a no. They have no people skills and should be put through training to be able to manage people. I'll put it this way, if I was a customer and my supervisor was the customer service rep, they'd fail miserably. They don't care about their employees but mask the unprofessional lack of proper training by having a bbq once every 2 months. Or having in house raffles of trinkets no one cares for since they are not usable on the call floor.  They live by the motto: do only that which you can't designate to others. Which means that they pass on their work to those below them but get more pay.

review_title: Express Scripts has come a long way
job_title: Senior Communications Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Express Scripts is a "doer" organization that doesn't waste time when it comes to making changes. Yes, office politics play into this and can slow a process down however, if you have an idea, you are empowered to execute it. 

There are plenty of opportunities to network internally and grow, even outside of your current role. Whether that's participating in an Employee Resource Group or scheduling a meeting over coffee, everyone understands the importance of growing your network and will take time to contribute. 

Express Scripts rewards hard work and will attempt to give employees opportunities that they ask for in order to grow professionally. 

There is a drive to be the best and do the right thing for the patients, the clients and the healthcare industry. Those are two sides of a coin that are hard to balance but Express Scripts does it better than most.
cons:
The company can operate in silos, as expected from an organization so large. However, they understand the need to be more collaborative and cross-functional. They also continue to up their communications game in order to help employees feel a part of change.

The culture can still feel very "corporate." There's a desire to be the Googles and Apples of the world, but change is slow to catch up, even if you can wear jeans every day. 

Meetings. So many meetings. 

More often than not, employees are carrying the weight of 1.5 or 2 people. There is a need to staff up in order to achieve the aggressive goals that the company sets for itself and to participate in better work/life balance practices.

review_title: Horribly run company with a lot of growing up to do
job_title: Senior Account Executive in Atlanta, GA
pros: Turn over is very high so you my get promoted if you are willing to deal with the company
cons:
Every department that you talk to within the company feels over worked and understaffed.  Some of this is due to ineffective leadership/management which is blatantly obvious in certain departments but in many cases such as account management it is a direct result of the company not wanting to staff accordingly.  Account managers are stretched so thin that any new recruits who are decent get fed up and all leave.  The worst part of it all is that company management KNOWS that account management is stretched thin and instructs account managers to flat out lie to their clients, telling them that they only have 10 or so accounts while in reality they have 20+.  

Early in the year the company decided to promote Tim Wentworth, to president.  With this change we heard all about putting the client first, fixing the all the problems that integration caused and he mentioned the term "operational excellence" and how we had lots of work to do to get to where he wanted to be.  Then came the 2Q earnings where Wallstreet questioned our costs and the company went right back to trying to cut costs. 

This fall should see even more cuts in budgets for next year and even more cuts to jobs in various parts of the company.

job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Barely the paycheck, close to public transportation
cons: Only the suck ups get promotions, its very dramatic, racist , and clique-y. My supe was actually a good supe, even though I dont think she liked me. I dont care . We had metrics to meet to get a bonus , the cap on the bonus in my dept was like 300 for a quarter, then they tax that so it was like an extra $50 on your check. Then the breaks , OMG the building is so big that unless you were close to a bathroom that was your whole break, then they gave us a bit a of freedom with our 30 minutes, use it how you like in whatever incriments,  but if you use it that way on certain days omg...napalm. Im all about adaptation, so I can adapt but here was not a place I could thrive. If you go to school online, dont have any kids, arent ambitious enough to want anything past this OR if you play the politics of it , youll be okay. If you just want an income without bs , not for you. Twice a person in a leadership position who was NOT the same ethnicity as me made a negative  comment about my hair texture. People would frequently make comments that were of a low frequency and become upset when you responded back with the same level of respect.

review_title: Work environment is poor but the pay is good for as long as they let you keep your job
pros: The pay is ok for the St. Louis area and the co-workers are very good. Nice new and clean buildings and a good cafeteria.
cons:
Demand for very long working hours  55-75/wk is the norm
No recognition for extreme efforts.  I've been told by my supervisors that they refuse to acknowledge hard working employees because then they would just come to expect it.
There is little to no opportunity for career growth and advancement.  Little to no training opportunity.  Supposedly there is a education benefit but the managers refuse to approve even job related classes.
Most mid to higher level jobs are all filled by people outside the company.  The few promotions you do see take forever.  Not uncommon to work at an advanced level for 5+ years before promotion to that authority level.
Management places little value on the experience and business knowledge of employees
Budgeting and estimating are extremely poor.  Deadlines are determined without any basis in the amount of work required or the number and skills of the workers available.
The company is also embracing the off-shore business model.  There are a few departments now that are committed to sending much of their staff overseas and it looks like this concept will be expanded on in the future.

review_title: Run away if you want a career; stay if you just need the money
job_title: Business Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
- Pays Ok
- Ability to work from home; though this varies from team to team
- Good benefits especially PTO for corporate employees
- Very stable business model with no exciting changes
cons:
- Minimal Guidance & Training:
Don't expect any guidance or technical resource supporting your role; management just wants you to start producing numbers for them instead of giving you development opportunities. Minimal training is given and the rest is on you to figure everything out.

- Bureaucracy & Favoritism:
Bureaucracy is all over the place here. There are probably more VPs in some departments than analysts which is laughable. If you want to survive here, kiss up the CORRECT higher-up will help you a long way. You will get fast tracked in your career by becoming their favorites; however if you are not one of those favorites, you are out of luck & will stay in your position probably forever.

-  No accountability:
With the bureaucracy they had over here it's more important to make sure your boss & your boss's boss look good than doing actual work so people would make up numbers and nobody would want to do any implementation on anything. Plus nobody checks on whether your number is correct or not, so fake it until you make it (& nobody will ever make it)!

- Siloed working environment:
A lot of teams work in huge silos even sub-teams within the same org don't talk to each other. Nobody knows what's going on with the other group. This basically makes collaboration impossible.

review_title: How can so good turn so bad
pros:

When it was Medco, I was told several times by people I would meet how satisfied they were with the service we provided, never any problems That was a great feeling.
cons:
Managers appear not to know or care what is happening on the later shifts.
Supervisors need to stop acting like they are Gods gift to women.
Supervisors are not knowledgeable of there area , need to learn what is going on.
Supervisors will send home people and then bring in OT to cover. Horrible business practices.
Managers let people control what they are suppose to do instead of taking charge, Supervisors just do not want confrontations so the let the Shop Stewart do what he wants.
Supervisor does not make people do there jobs, cater to some while others struggle.
ESI needs to stop the fashion shows in some areas and make these people do there jobs.

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Memphis, TN
pros: Decent pay to begin with and bonuses are possible. Discount on health benefits for nonsmokers. Overtime available when it's offered. Relaxed dress code.
cons: Starting out you spend 3-4 weeks in basic training. Learning the history of Express Scripts and basic customer service training. When training is over they pull names out of a hat to determine who goes where. Once on your new team you may be placed with different people who may or may not follow procedure and you're expected to learn from them. You're taught in training about ethics of the company and how the patients and clients are #1 but there are just too many questionable moments that feel like that's not what's really important. There are Supervisors in position who don't seem to know much and can't really assist you properly. Some Team Leaders are more personable and easier to work with than Supervisors.  There's no consistency with leadership.  The gossiping & cliques among leadership and employees is ridiculous. There are contracted employees who make more money & survive layoffs while permanent employees are kicked to the side. Most team meetings were held for the Supervisor to rant & rave about the negative while positive acknowledgment was null & void. Being an "All In" employee didn't seem to get me very far.

job_title: Senior Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The company continues to make strides in changing the perception of the culture.  The new CEO not only promotes Integrity, Mutual Respect and Passion, but seems very genuine in living it daily.  Leadership has learned that employees have varying needs that must be met in order to be more successful in their role, contribute to the overall success of the company, and view the company as a positive workplace.  Whether it's an attractive bonus structure for financially driven employees, or a flexible schedule for those driven by a better work-life balance, new initiatives are being implemented to meet specific needs and ensure that good employees are retained, and good talent is attracted.
cons: The changes being made to improve the perception of the culture is a work in progress that is going to take time.  Some long time employees and leaders find it difficult to accept and allow some of the new changes, which has lead to frustration of employees in their areas who feel they may not have the same access to the improved opportunities.  Additionally, some of the new initiatives and changes are not clearly defined or understood, which can cause confusion and conflict.

pros:

Work was challenging and there is a lot to do.  I think the company tries to be a good employer but managers listen to consultants and themselves and not the people in the trenches so their efforts are not as effective.
cons:
Horrible work live balance - so bad they stopped using to term around me.  

In many cases GE forced rankings are politically decided and then annual reviews are made to fit the rating which I find dishonest and unfair.

Very poor investment in people and software technology.  Could be move effective if they had better feedback loops like chargeback on infrastructure and invested in software technology - better tools, current tools at a reasonable release - rather than changing after software goes off support.

Their cost saving plans hurt some patients, including me.  They should give doctors more control over the care of patients and not squeeze as much out of stingy pharmacy benefits so they can make higher profits.

Managers tend to live in ivory towers and look down on and disregard the workes.

Pay is average. There are fine people working here but you generally don't make friends with them cause they don't stick around long. Its is a Fortune 500 company so that does look real good on your resume. You might learn Oracle if they ever get it working right so that's good too.
Nice clean bathroom all over the place. Free parking and a nice lake to walk around.
cons: Very negative place to work. HR is very keen on hiring people who all fit certain groups and ignoring the other group. Benefits are really low for a Fortune 500 they give just the bare bones when it come to them giving you benefits. Had better 401 match at a company that only had one location and like 400 employees. Have to work overtime with very little notice. Your wont get promotion or pay increase unless you are liked by your supervisor no matter how good a worker you are  cause they don't like you and forget about bonuses cause they are in charge of who gets a bonus too. Never hear any real news on what the place is trying  to do  they just change things around and say it will make us more productive but it doesn't. job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Tempe, AZ
pros:
Work life balance (finally), employee incentives and recognition, National work at home program, pay is competitive, eligible for benefits before 3 months

**I have worked here for over 5 years and in the beginning things were ok, mostly because the benefits pretty much saved my family financially when my husband needed expensive health treatments for 6 months.  My leaders were willing to work with my schedule to accomadate me.  Things took a turn south about 3 years in.  Very little employee recognition was given, the bonuses sucked, and the work environment was stagnant.  Starting in 2015 and more so this year (2016), senior leadership has been making a valiant effort in bringing up morale, providing better work life balance, paying better bonuses (still leaves something to be desired though) and giving better raises and even giving the building a new interior design with better equipment for the employees
cons: Benefits have gotten more expensive and seem to cover less, bonuses still leave a little to be desired for us "little people", needing to work full 40 hour work weeks and sometimes with 10% or more overtime on top of that on holiday weeks and then coming in and not having the work to support it gets frustrating and seems like a huge waste of time

pros: Great PTO, good benefits, some flexible scheduling such as work at home as long as your manager gets behind work at home.
cons: There is almost no opportunity for advancement unless you know the right people and that isn't saying much. Rewards go to those who follow scripting but don't think much. Just saw someone get "circle of excellence" who regularly screws up and can barely compose a sentence. It makes it difficult to give your all to a company that rewards you with average reviews when you are a work horse and try hard to give the very best customer service. . Its fine if you don't expect to much but the stress level for a front line job is terrible. I make about $3 more an hour than I did 8'years ago. The only reason I stay is I'm tired of the job hunt and getting ready to retire. Also I love my coworkers. Since the merger it's gotten worse and I think it's safe to say there is a fair share of bitterness from former Medco employees.  I don't know how long I'm going to be able to keep it up.

review_title: Named 2nd worst company to work for in America by the Wall Street Journal two years in a row (should be #1 by next year)
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Decent benefits, 401K, TR, PTO (but good luck using it), nice HQ in St. Louis. Some genuinely nice people still remain. Can work from home or go into the office.
cons:
I have watched ESI fall to pieces over the last few years. I can now state without any uncertainty or hesitation  that things will never improve. It's become too much of a mess. Most in leadership are simply not qualified, don't care, or are too busy to care. No clear career path and absolutely no training. Everyone's job is to just "try and figure it out" without asking too many questions. Everyone is miserable at this point with the biggest issue being work/life balance.....If you use one day of PTO, you will work 10-12 hour days for the next 5 days upon returning trying to catch up. So, if you use 1 full week of PTO, you will work approximately 25 consecutive 10-12 hour days upon your return. 

The culture at ESI is cut throat and very negative and hostile. As other reviewers have mentioned, this is not a happy, positive place to be. Every organization will have their share of issues, but, I can't imagine anything coming close to what my colleagues and myself have witnessed and endured. 

My advise to the potential ESI employee reading this - if you are presently employed and can at least tolerate your current job STAY WHERE YOU ARE. After 6 months of working at ESI, you will surely regret the day you ever applied or were recruited.

pros: Health insurance coverage is comparable to most other offerings in corporate America. There is also access to stock purchase which can be good investment for the future.
cons: Very demanding, they expect you to keep your head down, your mouth shut and want you to be working every minute you're on site. In the call center you have to log out of the phone using a code for personal(bathroom) breaks and lunch. You have a computerized time clock that is always non-functioning causing you to have to write your time down and keep track for yourself because if your punches are missing you have to fill in the blanks because the time clock only maintains one day of punches. Any missed time is automatically taken from your PTO whether it is made up or not if you don't specify that you're going to make it up. Which you may not know your punches are missing. So you could wind up losing PTO hours and still have over 80 hours that's paid at straight time. By the way not all supervisors calculate time this way, some wait to see if there is made up time before robbing your PTO. They openly show preferences toward "favorites" and openly treat "non-favorites" harshly and hostile. The prevailing attitude is you need to be glad you have a job!. You always feel that your job is in jeopardy. One supervisor has said repeatedly in open meetings."If you're complaining and don't like something then maybe this isn't the place for you!"

review_title: It has been a tumultuous ride with view of corporate bureaucracy at it's finest.
job_title: Software Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The new headquarters is very nice. The cafeteria is excellent. They pay contractors very well. They've attempted to advance their technologies. Everyday is a new challenge. The corporation continues to grow.
cons:
They treat employees like commodities rather than humans, unless of course you are connected to the right manager. If you know the right people then you receive all the praise and job security that you would ever need.

They need to stop existing in constant emergency mode. For a company so large and with so much resources available to them they could easily cultivate the knowledge and experience that they have gained so that development and implementation could occur in an orderly fashion with far fewer mistakes. 

Every time they let someone go all of the knowledge that the person has gained just walks right out the door. Management does not seem to understand the huge expense associated with this loss. It takes 3 months for a new person to become fully productive and it could take up to a year or more to become an expert.  You spend all of that time training that person only to dismiss them? Does this make sense?

review_title: Would NOT recommend unless it is to my absolute worst enemy.
pros: Pay was decent.  Benefits were decent.... nothing else.
cons: Workers that are slacking are often lauded the one time they do something good.  Workers that consistently give good work are swept under the rug.  Favoritism is rampant which disgusts me.  There is borderline sexual harassment occurring and for the 200+ cameras they have around the facility, I cannot believe that it was not seen or anything done about it.  They do not care about physical or emotional well-being (unless you are a favored worker, then they cater obscenely to you).  Supervisors are annoyed when you ask questions and often just send you to another employee to get an answer.  They give off this air of not wanting to be bothered at all.  Supervisors are usually always on their cell phones playing games.  I have even seen one on their phone showing another employee a rather inappropriate video.  Again nothing is seen or done.  I guess the cameras are just for decoration.  Supervisors heavily socialize with the favored workers, slowing work.  Again, the workers that DO actually do good work often feel forgotten and left out.  Morale is in the pits and I can see why there is high turnover for the decent workers.

review_title: Values of the organization do not match how they treat employees
pros: The company can provide a lot of opportunities for someone who wants to get involved in various projects and learn different things.
cons: There is not much support for making mistakes, which makes it difficult to raise your hand and take on new things.  So while the company can offer a lot of opportunities to learn, people tend to stick to what they know they can do versus trying very new things.  This does not apply to everyone, but it applies to the vast majority of people.  There is a culture of being overly critical and pointing out others' mistakes (usually covertly) with the aim of discrediting others to make yourself look better.  This is in opposition to the values of mutual respect and collaboration that adorn the walls.  This is coming from an employee that has been treated well and advanced (versus disgruntled) but has noticed the culture over time is misaligned with what the claim they want to be.  Additionally, they seem to bring on a lot of people to help them get through special projects or help implement new clients and then fire them afterward.  They don't fire just those who don't execute, but the "excess" they knowingly bring on and who have done a good job.  The feeling is that they "use up" people until the company decides they don't want them any longer.

review_title: Used to be a good place to work
pros: Compensation in IT is generally competitive, benefits are decent.  Paid time off is good, when you're allowed to take it.
cons: After touting all the accomplishments of the IT team in recent years, upper management proceeded this last year to basically dismantle that very same team and replace a lot of people with outsourced contractors.  This used to be a good place to work in IT, with good collaboration between teams and opportunities to learn and apply new technologies.  Now it's just about pushing ambitious projects through with impossible deadlines.  All projects are managed "by crisis", people are overworked and product quality is suffering.  Project managers often don't understand what they're managing.  This company basically sells information technology services for the health care industry, and yet treats IT as an expense, not as a revenue generator.  They're foolishly counting on the economic downturn to get the most out of their employees without having to worry about keeping them happy.  "You need to work harder, because the alternative is to be unemployed" is a popular "pep talk" given by management.

review_title: A chance to be a change agent in improving healthcare in the US
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: Working for Express Scripts is an opportunity to actually make a difference in improve the quality and cost of healthcare in the US.  I finish every day knowing that I accomplished something important.  Is it a challenging environment?  Absolutely.  But that challenge is what keeps us on our toes and doing our best work.  Overall, I work for kind people who are fair and always providing positive feedback. They have a personal life and are supportive when my personal life (i.e. kids, family) need my attention.  During Super Storm Sandy, by boss was the first to call me to see if I was ok.  And I had only been working for him for 6 months. I miss my Medco colleagues, and adjusting to a new work culture from afar has been hard.  But Express Scripts is a good place with good people who are all working to make the cost of health care more affordable for patients and payers.
cons: Being a remote employee, I do not feel as if there are as many growth opportunities as there were before the merger.  While frustrating, I don't believe the grass would be "greener" elsewhere.  I earn a fair salary, I have good benefits for my family and my retirement, and I have a good work/life balance.

job_title: Information Technology in Saint Louis, MO
pros: There are many quality people working at Express Scripts.
cons: HR department does not have a clue how to screen for, how to evaluate positions, and what functions are actually performed by IT positions.  This ignorance about IT positions causes them to undercompensate for certain roles within the IT department which leads to a revolving door.  HR also has a misconception about the difference between a contractor and an independent contractor.  I know in one instance that a contractor was there for almost 18 months and the HR department forced this person to accept a perm position for 35% less or have to leave the company because they said that it was a law that contractors cannot work for more than 18 months.  Some of the IT groups that are on call for the weekends must remain available and are not compensated for their availability.  The on call person only gets paid if they get called.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Memphis, TN
pros: Co-workers were nice. Training was very helpful. Benefits are great!
cons: Upper management was terrible. The job says to be able to work under minimal supervision, however workers there felt they were under full supervision.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Benefits package is decent. When I first started with ESI, I really enjoyed the company and its values. However, over time as it appeared that being the biggest PBM became the focus, the company lost their way.
cons: Leadership was terrible overall. It seemed that senior leadership became disengaged with what was actually happening to those on the front line with patients and clients. With that said, it is ironic that in one place I worked for one of the best managers I ever worked for as well as one of the worse. However, most of the managers I had were more task oriented and not truly qualified to manage people. The employee ranking system (bell curve) for reviews is terrible and out-of-date. It only lowered moral around review time and created a "me" or "cya" mentality at any cost and made teamwork less effective as well as some employee actions questionable. Teamwork should be promoted more for the betterment of the company and employees.

job_title: Operations Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: George is gone. The culture has already improved. Cheap, feeble minded strategies should now retire with King George the Terrible.
cons: Time to start unraveling his mess.  Lots of changes to make.  Years of bad managing will take time to fix.

pros: Good pay, Flexibility to work from home
cons: Too corporate, too demanding and not to friendly

pros: hours are flexible for this position
cons: pay below market for this position

pros: There are no pros, stay away
cons: This is the absolute worst company I have every worked for. There is a serious lack of communication all around, from upper management to HR. HR is quick to screw up your paycheck and take their precious time to fix it. You could go without a paycheck for as long as three weeks, meanwhile they are giving you the runaround saying that they've expedited things and you will be updated in 2-3 business days. Meanwhile you could be waiting as long as three weeks. Same thing with benefits, they screw up your benefits you call to get it resolved you spend 30 minutes on the phone with someone who can't give you a direct answer they escalate the issue and tell you that you will get a c/b in 48hrs. Meanwhile you wait for two weeks and no one has called or email and you're calling them for an update every two days and they have no updates they're still investigating. Two months later and there is still no resolution but they expect you to come to work every day get paid scraps and keep a smile on your face. Oh and they treat the customers the same way. They don't update their employees on changes in a timely manner, when something changes you ask your supervisor what's going on. Of course they ignore you because they have no idea. Two weeks later you get a mass email informing you of the change. Meanwhile you've been winging it for two weeks. Don't bother with this place its not worth the time, energy, headache, high blood pressure or hair loss.

pros: Good health insurance, good shifts
cons: Don't value the employee. And that is very sad

pros: Love the calls, the clients
cons: The Pay is very low.

review_title: Only take the job if you have no other choice
pros: Most people are generally friendly, at least a few people are willing to collaborate in each department.  The majority of employees try to do a good job
cons:
Everything else.  There is no work-life balance for anyone, even for direct supervisors.  Management is expected to give the lip-service about patient care and quality of work but outside of meetings everyone knows there is too much red tape, miscommunication, and poor training to get the work done correctly.  This company cares about its bottom line, never let them tell you different.

The pay depends on who you worked for before the merger.  From the Medco side, they have announced massive layoffs and closed entire facilities, then hired on the Express Scripts side for lower pay.  With lower pay comes less experience, just another barrier to quality care for the patient.  Raises and bonuses have been frozen for 3 years and I don't expect that to change.  The employees have nothing to work towards or achieve other than their next paycheck and that is the only thing that keeps most of us there until we can find something else.

They also REQUIRE you to use their services or the prescription plan won't cover the medications at the same rate.  I've learned that this requirement isn't just for employees, its also for patients (including my own mother who works for company in contract to Express Scripts.)

I have never, EVER felt so undervalued as an employee.

review_title: It might be growing but only for some
pros: Nice location at HQ and good, hard working people work there. NIce amenities available such as the onsite oil change, car wash
cons: Micro-managed to death! People who don't have enough knowledge and know-how are promoted to people leaders without knowing how to truly lead. Leaders Lead - I think not. Career paths are pointless unless you are someone's friend. Management's idea that employees will train themselves is flawed. You are thrown into the fire immediately with little to no training or direction. In some of these departments, if you can walk and chew gum at the same time you're a manager but they are totally ineffective and imcompetent, and always ready to point the finger at someone else if something goes wrong.  Total lack of employee support from direct management, they are always worried about looking good at the next level, will throw their employees under the bus if they think it will allow them to be unscathed.

review_title: People are only as good as their management and leadership!
job_title: Project Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: There are some very good areas to work within Express Scripts.  There are good knowledgeable staff that embrace consultants and contractors.
cons:
Managementn lacks vision.  Management did not hold staff meetings to convey information across all levels.  Management treated consultants much differently than perm employees.  Management also continually hammered to consultants that Project Managers were always going to be consultants.  Express Scripts also has a annual calibration feedback system that evaluates an employees work based all internal customers and others feedback determining their racking and stack against others.   Concept here is to weed out the week and the ones left will grow and learn from the experience.  They - management - does not grow their team nor do they listen to consultatns to optimize and streamline their internal processes 

The Program Management community within Express Scripts is going through (rolling out)  major changes.  There is a lot of internal overhead (fluff) that monitors metrics and scorecards that are not consistent across various department/verticals.  Remove the fluff and force managers to do their jobs would eliminate a lot of waste of money.

pros: You have to potential to learn a lot.  Things move fast so you get to see lots of issues and situations come up. It is an interesting industry so there is a lot to learn from that side as well. I would say the benefits and PTO is acceptable.
cons:
Every team works in silos. Everyone only wants to own their one area and have nothing to do with upstream or downstream processes. There have been so many director level and above firings in the last few years that no one wants to put their neck out. If there is an error, senior management may be looking for a scapegoat instead of trying to attempting to coach and retain talent. 

It is also an extremely meeting heavy culture, another sign of the bureaucracy. Most people will not pick up the phone and many get so overloaded with emails that the only way to reach them is out 30 minutes on the calendar. Most directors and above that I know have meetings booked solid, often double and triple booked, from 9-5.

Compensation is below market, though many higher up in the company have massive paychecks. There is always the pressure to work more. My group is more lax than others but my unwillingness to regularly work more than 50 hours a week will probably be career limiting.

pros: Some of the employees that work for the Express Scripts truly care about their work, and are passionate about the pharmaceutical industry.
cons: All levels of employees could use a course in professionalism (including Directors, and HR), no job security, unstable company, the company makes impulsive decisions at all levels.

review_title: manipulative horrendous unconscionable place to work
job_title: Calling Tech in North Versailles, PA
pros: 2 breaks and a lunch I worked for FlexRX. then Merk bought us out then medco came on board then it was just Medco.everything was good.
cons: the merger with express scripts has been extremely stressfull for all involved.We have seen some nice people loose their jobs.Supervisers pharmacists and techs gone.George Paz has no idea how to run a pharmacy he's just a business man who's only concern is how much money he can stuff in his pocket.The CEO has fired $1million in people at the north versailles Pa facility then hired 2 schmoes to run the facility like its a production line.Numbers are the bottom line.How many you do in an hour. When calling adoctor or patient every call is scrutinized.Every word and pause and breath is scrutinized .We actually get REPORT CARDS on our calls.Points taken off if we paused too long or short. And now these schmoes they hired have RUN THE BUSINESS BOARDS which have turned out to be the biggest joke on the face of this earth. The moral at this facility is at below rock bottom.I don't believe there is one happy employee except the 2 schmoes they hired to RUN THE BUSINESS .

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Orlando, FL
pros: Benefits are ok.  401k is a good match.
cons: If you are into high school antics, co-workers sleeping with management (and the company doing nothing about it), .30 or less raises a year, favoritism galore, being treated like you're a preschooler   and being lied to constantly- THIS IS THE PLACE FOR YOU!  No respect whatsoever for this company and those that work there and run the place.  If you have prior experience and present it to them it goes in one ear and out the other.  Jobs are rewarded to friends, family or those management are sleeping with.  Have received ONE RAISE since starting there.  An increase in wage due to the Department of Defense contract stating the wage had to be met was presented to us as our raise even though we worked diligently all year long prior to this.  VERY UNFAIR PRACTICES BY THIS COMPANY.  their Core Practices ARE A JOKE and never practiced.  Training you go through regarding practices are never followed.  Team Leads have NO CLUE how to be leaders and inspire others to do better.  If you enjoy being "chained" to your desk for 8+ hours and are expected to take no bathroom breaks and possibly give up your lunch, THIS IS THE JOB FOR YOU.  Majority of TLs received their jobs in an unfair way, most of them not even understanding the business they're in.  I have had numerous high paying jobs prior to moving to FL.  This job is pathetic.

job_title: Appliation Developer in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: Some teams are managed tightly and properly, some are discorded and overloaded
cons: If you are on a team that is overloaded you will have no work life balance

review_title: It's Better with the Union on your Side
pros: Union Negotiated a better Health Plan for Legacy Medco Union Sites than ESI offered(lower deductible and out of pocket, Rx cost are only $10 & $30 for 90 day supplies or $5 & $15 at retail and we can go to local pharm. as many times as we want ), No pay cuts for employees already hired before March 1st 2013) we kept our Vacation & Time Bank without losing any days and we get them upfront like we always have (non-union employees lost up to 7 days depending on how long they have been with the company & they earn a percentage for every 40 hrs), We have a Union that is there to make sure that our rights are protected.
cons: Legacy Medco Management seems lost, they are over micro-managing - ESI has implemented things that make no sense, and are trying to run things out of satellite offices to control several buildings.  They do not care about employees, they only care about numbers, the  acquisition has killed our spirit, and our care.  The Legacy Medco people use to LIKE coming to work now- We are there for a PAYCHECK!

pros: In my position, I am fairly compensated.
cons: Work load is unmanageable, which creates a very high stress level.  Regularly work 12 plus hours a day.  Sadly, even doing so you are still behind.  It is really competitive to the point that you never know who you can trust.  Hard work does get compensated but also gets you more work with even higher expectation.  Their is very little concern for employees well being, which is ironic since we are part of the healthcare system.  We should know the importance of work/life balance to have happy and healthy employees.  Long hours, high stress, lack of sleep and little personal time can have negative effects on your employees physical and mental health. The PTO should just be referred to as flex time because no one covers your load while you are out so you are still working those hours, just at a different time.

pros: If there were any, I’d have stayed
cons: Like Office Space, too many mgrs with no clue what to do but remind you of any mistake 7x

job_title: Senior IT Project Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Stable employment with good salaries and benefits
cons: Ideas are not always acknowledged

pros: For me, the best reason is that it is close to my home.  If you prefer repetitive, routine work, then you may like it.
cons:
It's "all about the numbers".  More emphasis is placed on productivity numbers than customer service.  Expected productivity rates are unrealistic and result in associates doing whatever is necessary to make the rates, which includes shortcuts that do not result in beneficial outcomes, .  Customer service gets lip service only, it is not a priority, which is evident for customers and Dr's offices who call in and cannot talk to a live person because so many departments use voice mail as a first line.
Not many advancement opportunities for pharmacists.  Loads of Supervisor positions for technicians since they are paid less. Pharmacists are not valued for their knowledge or experience.  If you can't make the numbers,  you are out.

pros:
Paycheck
Free soda and food you can scrounge for
cons:
Too much time and money wasted
Poor management of projects and people
Core values are a joke and not visible anywhere

review_title: Terrible, Terrible, Terrible Place To Work
job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Depending on what department you were in you could work from home which was nice. I started out as a pharmacy tech and was able to move up in the company.
cons:
Pharmacy benefits with this company are a joke. The home delivery system is broken. My neighbor has tried for weeks to get his medications but ESI can't seem to get the drugs delivered to his house, then they tell him he has to pay AGAIN for the replacement of the drugs that THEY lost in shipping. My spouse had lots of problems getting the monthly medications delivered on time. It's major drama calling in to get a person who can assist you and when you do finally connect to a live person all you get is bad attitude.  
Management is out of touch with its employees because they have too many reporting to them. Supervisors were overloaded with work and no work/life balance. 
Year end reviews were a joke. You could walk on water in your position but management is forced to put employees in a less favorable status whether it was true or not. Mid year reviews were never completed by mid year but usually by September. Year End reviews weren't discussed until at least March. 
Training of any kind was lackluster at best.
Constant fear of being let go.
George Paz.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Whitestown, IN
pros: Healthcare pay rate work schedule employment process
cons: Big Employee turnaround, negative atmosphere, sonority prejudicial prejudicing

job_title: Pricing Manager in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: People are nice. Most have your back
cons: Stressful environment and fast paced.

review_title: Corporate job where you are a number and part of a big machine
job_title: Resolution Team Lead / ASC  in Bloomington, MN
pros:
Job Stability as long as you meet call metrics if in call center and meet unrealistic goals.  Company is not going anywhere.

Good Benefits, 401k match, employee stock programs
cons: Management has no idea what you do.  They only are about saving a dime not about what is practical and realistic.  Job itself I can relate to PSD (Post traumatic stress disorder).  I have seen this company change people for the worse and destroy who they once were.  When I left it took me 2 years to un-program what the company did to my mind and well being.  I worked for the company for over 9 years and I am still not the person I was before I worked for ESI.

review_title: Variable experiences, some positive some negative.  Hard to get used to sitting all day.
pros: It is close to my home.   Very successful company financially.   Incomparable health benefits (we are union employees).   Friendly coworkers.   Friendly lower management.  Salary is ok when you consider the excellent health benefits.
cons: Very difficult to sit in a chair for hours on end; causes neuropathy and other pain.   Only two 15 minute breaks allowed to walk around and get your blood flowing again.  Only 1/2 hour for lunch - not enough time to relax and rejuvenate.  Upper management is very unfriendly.  When ESI lost money acquiring Medco, they cut us to part time to pay for it while the managers kept full time hours.  They don't appreciate their employees at all and continue to push for more and more efficiency to the point of being unsafe.  Most employees are depressed and taking medication for it.  Very low morale, but people stay because of the health benefits and unavailability of other decent employment.   Very hard to get time off when you need it - they could care less.

job_title: Data Entry Technician in Fairfield, OH
pros: Even though the medical benefits have been on the decline since ESI bought out Medco, they are still better than many places that i know of with a comparable wage in my region.
cons: Everything is micromanaged, down to the exact second that you clock in or out or whether or not you remember to leave your desk completely empty (with your chair pushed in). Daily meetings consist mostly of complaints to or from management, but nothing ever comes of them...management is consistently hassled and grumpy and you never hear from your supervisor unless you're doing something wrong...so the environment is incredibly negative. You are forbidden from speaking to your neighbor, as well as emailing them or IM'ing them. While they believe that this is for increased productivity, humans are not machines. Working there was miserable and soul-draining.

review_title: Great job in a horrible atmosphere
job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Saint Marys, GA
pros: Extremely easy job. IF you can't do this job, there isn't a job you could do.
cons:
The management in this building reminds me of the stereotypical "in crowd" in a generic television high school. Get in with them, and your career here will soar. Don't, and be prepared to do the same thing for as long as you are here. I watched someone with 3 years experience here get promoted in a manner that made them  directly in charge of someone with 12 years of experience. 

Additionally, management has been fighting the high turnover rate since at least 2010, but that is a problem with an obvious answer, and they pretend they can't see it. All of the ridiculous, childish, and downright patronizing "fun" activities like theme days and pizza parties and paper awards make one feel as if they have returned to their high school days, which pairs with my aforementioned description of the management staff rather well. 

Also, Avaya is the most aggravating phone system I have had the displeasure of using.

job_title: Senior Data Entry Certified Pharmacy Tech in Troy, NY
pros: it works for me, i came from retail pharmacy and like any job it had favoritism and i was one of the favorites.  It is a little different at express but so what, it pays the bills, no one bothers me and I get the time off I need.  I like my manager, in fact I have liked them all and if there was a problem I figured it out like a grown up.  Express has been flexible with my health issues and school issues , the pay is decent the reward according to the work you do not some preset rate so that works for me because I work hard, if you work hard you will be rewarded if you coast, they will notice and you will be rewarded accordingly , thus the complaints.  I will stay as long as they have me.
cons: just the software , hopefully it gets better with the merger  and some of the complaining but but at my site we rock

review_title: Good place to work if you don't mind compromising your humanity
job_title: Pharmacy Benefit Manager in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: Independent work, work from home, nice office area when in the office.  Some staff is helpful and available for questions.
cons: Management is almost a myth, barely ever in the office.  Very confrontation averse culture; management communicates through email and instant messenger, or a very rare phone call.  Training was minimal for a process that was very strategic and required high cognitive processing, and get yelled at when you do it wrong.  One manager in particular was a screamer, and nothing was done while he was making a spectacle of himself in the office.  Management plays favorites and gives work to their *stars* who apparently understood everything on day 1.  Was told to ask for work when you had "bandwidth" but was usually already given to the favorite people; then you got condescending remarks when you were expected to sit at your desk with no work to do, even after asking repeatedly for it.  People who clearly should've been let go, were kept on for the length of the contract.  Was informed of a three month extension, and then ended my contract the following week.  Pay was awful.

pros: Vacation if you could take it. They  do not have enough open slots to accommodate all the employees vacations for the year.
cons: Quality of life/ Quota work.  Causes unnecessary daily stress.  Have to work until completed a "stretch" number of points.   Most Work at Home pharmacists have to work significantly over 40 hours each week.  There are pharmacists who work 60-70 hrs each week to hit the quota.   The production results in facilities are much lower than those for the Work at Home team.  Management brags about the extreme Work at Home pharmacist production levels. Well of course,  teams of pharmacist who work over 50 hours a week will be more productive than those who only work 40 hours per week.  Upper management response “this job is not for everyone”.   So lets recap: you get paid for 40 hours but your work week is much over that.  Management claims most pharmacist only work 40 hours/wk but amazingly all your coworkers are working as much as you.   Also since everyone has the same production numbers it is very difficult to get an Exceeds on your evaluations for your annual raise.

review_title: Express Scripts manages to the bottom line and exploits everything including employees.
job_title: Senior Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
A performance leader with HQ in Saint Louis.  Pays slightly better than most companies in Saint Louis.   Respected by financial analyst for continued growth.  Tough and relentless competitor.

Given the economy, they offer a solid place to work for anyone that wants a couple of years compensation in exchange for a massive amount of work.
cons:
Lip service is paid frequently to the value of employees, but anyone that is not a VP or viewed as potential future VP is cannon fodder.  All employees struggle to have any balance with family.

You're valued for what you're doing now and have to earn your job every day, and can be arbitrarily fired to meet financial targets or forced ranking quota.  I was hired by an exceptional VP, but discovered after she transferred that she was on of the rare really good department leaders.

People pay lip service to core values but its common to see them keeping information to themselves to get into the elite 20% stretch performers that are rewarded heavily.  

If you're not targeted as a stretch performer or capable for another promotion they will run you into the ground until you quit or they claim you're below thresholds and fire you.

review_title: Poor management, little interest in employees. OK as a starting job, not as a career.
job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Tempe, AZ
pros: Good employee atmosphere. Facilities are nice. Hours are consistent and they are always hiring.
cons:
Little opportunity for advancement, those opportunities that are available do not provide much of a pay raise. The company itself is not that concerned about employee's, you'll be met with an excuse for everything. Need a better chair with good back support? You'll be handed a thick packet to have your doctor fill out only to be told that the current chairs meet all your requirements. Want to bring your own? No it's a liability. They won't let you work at home unless your stats are near perfect (hard to achieve), I had to leave the company due to a disability. Was told that work at home was a privilege for top performers. I was in the top 10% of performing employee's, some weeks I was in the top 3-5%.

The worst part is that they are always changing policies that affect your workflow. As soon as you start getting comfortable and good at doing things one way, your made to do them another.

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Saint Marys, GA
pros: Liberal PTO, Health insurance premiums are based upon your salary range. Some VTO offered during over staffed hours. Ability to work from home.
cons: If you or your kids get sick and you need to call out that day, it's an attendance impact. So even if you met all their metrics, you lose any bonus you may have been entitled to.
