AHT is unrealistic, if you are truly being a Patient Care Advocate. You can also lose your bonuses if you don't do enough conversions from retail to mail order. They train you in too many cores so you are mediocre in everything instead of an expert in one or two. I could go on and on about quality score reviews, just another way to prevent you from earning your bonuses. Their equipment is outdated and it's like pulling teeth to get replaced. I work from home so everytime there is a thunderstorm and power goes out, it takes awhile to reboot your system.

pros: Decent benefits, annual bonus, nice cafeteria, a free bag on employee appreciation day, and e-mail from the CEO's secretary congratulating you on a service anniversary..
cons: Incompetent upper managment.  Our IT director 's previous job was at a brewery and explained that to truly understand the company, he spent a day in the brewery and doing deliveries, so, for us to understand Express Scripts, we should go visit its automated mail-order pharmacy.  If that doesn't show a total misunderstanding of the complexity of a pharmacy benefit management company, I don't know what does.  Yet these are the guys making the IT decisions.  Funny how none of the major screwups of recent software releases and the costs involved in fixing them make it into the management slide shows or the press.

job_title: Financial Analysis Lead Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Co Workers, Office Space, Free parking
cons: Salary, Benefits, Upward Mobility, Training

pros:
The one good thing is that I actually LOVE the work I do! I can sit at the computer all day, listen to music, and just type away. LOVE THAT! 

Okay second good thing is that I get paid for it. 

Yes, that is where the pros end though.
cons:
- Too impersonal. You barely get to know your manager or coworkers. I'm used to working in small environments where you got close to people. Not here.
- You are treated like a robot and that's it. Just sit there and type faster and faster and faster all while maintaining a ridiculous accuracy rate.
- Numbers numbers numbers. You are nothing but numbers which determine your 'worth'. Doesn't matter how good a person you are, if you show up on time every day, are there every day, don't call out, work hard, and don't fool around, etc. If your numbers aren't good enough, you're gone. I have seen so many people fired already it's crazy. They should put more effort into good people. But they don't care, it's like oh we can just replace you. Yeah great feeling to have over your head every day at work.
- The pay is horrible. For what they are paying they should reduce their expectations in terms of numbers. But like I said, it's like they use you until you're not good enough anymore, then it's bye bye.

review_title: PCA could be a great job, but for management
pros: The job has the potential to assist hundreds and thousand patients with their prescriptions.  It is a good feeling to be able to help people.   The other employees are great to work with.  Benefits are better than many other jobs.
cons: Local management has their favorites and will bend over backward for them to get them what they want even though there are others that do a much better job.  Sometimes it's like management doesn't know what they are doing and follow the leader around like puppy dogs.  The pay is low for the amount of knowledge you are expected to have and keeping up with all of the changes.  There are many scheduling issues and management only works well with their favorites and that includes supervisors.  Some times, it seems like they care less about the patients than making numbers for time on the phone, and getting people to transfer their prescriptions from retail to mail.  They talk about a work/life balance, but will not work fairly with employees schedules.  Talk about bonuses, but make it impossible to make some of the numbers.

review_title: A Part of my soul dies each time I punch the clock
pros:
generous PTO earning, roughly 6 hours per 80 hr pay period.
decent health benefits/affordable
cons:
MANY!
short notice mandatory overtime, no matter how badly it messes with your life.  
not a good place for people with children/families, students or people who like to sleep or have a life.
poor training
high school drama, only the in crowd gets promotions, raises, recognition
takes no brain power to do your job, a monkey could do it
high turn over
they preach "express way values" but don't live them
management that is totally out of touch with employees
you are just a number to your supervisor
"witch hunts" for anyone who isn't in a manager's pocket

job_title: Senior Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The teams I worked directly with were very hard working, no matter the issues they were hit with.
cons: Being in management, I can say the annual rankings are forced.  Employees are not graded on their own performance, but rather what HR directs us to rank them as.  We were unable to reward our hard working employees in the manner in which they earned.  New employees (with no experience) are brought in making more than long term employees.  Favoritism is rampant at all levels.  I was with the company for years, and have seen first hand gender bias at each level.  As employees left, and we were many times unable to replace, management is "forced" to get more out of remaining employees, with no sympathy for their home lives.  When I first started with the company, it was an awesome place to work, but in the last several years, especially since the merger, the company is in a downward spiral.  Many long standing, dedicated employees at the company have either been laid off, or left voluntarily due to the work environment.

job_title: Client Support Specialist in Orlando, FL
pros: Lengthy time of employment, able to make a career
cons: growth wasn't always consistent and expectations to grow were limited

job_title: Prior Authorization Representative in Liberty Lake, WA
pros: Decent benefits package through union membership (medical, dental, PTO, etc), colleagues look out for each other, supervisors who came up through the ranks tend to be more understanding.
cons: Few opportunities for advancement, no pay increases, bizarre time management rules, lack of communication from management, constant feeling of uncertainty over whether or not the site will continue to exist.

pros: Decent benefits. Lax attendance policy which is good because people hate this job and would rather call off and lose money than come in.
cons:
They force people on to "special projects", the biggest of which is "Compliance Reviewer" at the Dublin OH site. They dump extra work and responsibility on us for no additional pay, or compensation of any kind. People on special projects are held to much tighter metrics for gauging bonuses. When work is slow they will allow the normal representatives to leave and then make Compliance Reviewers do their work. The management in this place is a joke. Everyone of them is two-faced and can not be trusted. 
When clients come to visit they will "roll out the red carpet", which just means roll red tissue paper down the center of the call floor and yell at employees for walking on it. The pay here is well below the area average. Similar companies like Humana, Aetna, and Cardinal Health all pay 2-3 dollars an hour more for the same or similar job. Express scripts will also force to you do things that ethically are not right. Do not take this job unless you are absolutely desperate for employment. There's a reason this was rated the worst company to work for.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The company provided a nice facility for you to work...
cons: ESI was a very hard company to move up in. They set unrealistic expectations for you to fulfill as far as your raise was concerned. Your raise was also dependent upon others in your area, who may not have been doing the same or as much as you. I had a masters degree working in one of their call centers. I took the job to get in the company. It was very hard to not get clustered in with the others. If you weren't liked or well known...you can forget it. Also, if you move up while you're in the company, they will ONLY give you UP TO an 11% raise based on the current salary you have. IF they hired someone from outside without the internal experience and time with the company, you can guarantee they are making more money than you are.

review_title: Great pay - Loved my Supervisors and coworkers
job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Orlando, FL
pros: Full time hours - Good benefits - Time went by fast at work - Tons of calls kept me occupied and not bored - coworkers are typically up beat and are glad to be there.
cons: When Volunteer Time Off would come around sometimes they would not send out a mass email - Or they would offer very small windows of time where you could not logically leave for the day without having to come back to finish your shift

pros: The PTO, pay, snd benefits
cons: Literally everything else. This job will make you want to kill yourself

pros: Fun people, covered parking provided and I received a very fair wage.
cons: Was a great place to work several years ago, started going downhill 2 years before the Medco merger, I know see it was to be able to "buy" the competitor. Reputation of a sweatshop is accurate and you need to figure out how to work more and put your personal life on hold to continually fix broken processes. Code and enhancements are thrown in with flaws due to all of the high caliber employees running out the door for better opportunities. It's a constant fire drill to get things fixed, systems stabilized and keep the merger timeline ahead of schedule to keep Wall Street happy. People who are liked by their manager will go far because the evaluation process is just a popularity contest. Undeserving people are ranked low because the model requires there be a certain percentage of threshold employees. Raises are far less than the inflation rate and after the migration people expected to be rewarded for giving up their lives to work, even being called into the office during super storm Sandy. No regard for safety.

job_title: Senior Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The flexibility for all Express Scripts employees is great. Career advancement opportunities are plentiful. The paid-time-off package is second to none.
cons: Most people who do not enjoy working for Express Scripts site workload as their complaints. Express Scripts is a demanding fast-paced place to work. That is not a negative trait.

review_title: Strong focus on patients, integration and growth - none of which will happen without a change in employee strategy.
pros: The organization has a strong focus on operational success.  This includes a lean/continuous improvement culture focused on long term results for the patient and client, as well as a laser focus on successfully transferring patients to a single operating platform through integration.
cons: The Company has a fabulous rhetoric regarding how it values employees - on paper ("you belong here"); however, there is not enough integrity and skill throughout the organization to truly drive employee engagement.  Overall, tenure at the organization averages less than 5 years, the 2013 integrated benefit transition failed miserably on several fronts, with little or no sense of urgency from the highest level of the organization (including failing to enroll or continue employee benefits for 2 weeks to 2 months in some states).  Additionally, the compensation and total rewards strategy is driven by cost versus an intent to retain key contributors.

pros: The compensation was favorable especially if you are a high performer.
cons:
I worked as a pharmacist for Express Script from 2009 to 2015.  In 2015 Express Scripts was rated #1 worse company to work for.  I can confirm that in that year it was a very unprofessional environment to work for the MTM department.  Management was bias.  They didn't rotate holiday vacation as policy dictate.  When concerns were raised one senior manager said "One guy got 5 years off in a row and still complained!" as if it's OK to give someone 5 consecutive years off while other people were left off the holiday rotation.   This happened in a meeting and not in closed doors!

I also worked in another department that was managed much better so I can also make a case that it is Not the worst place to work for.  That would move my rating up.  Whether it is the worse or third worse, in the end numbers don't lie.  Unless drastic change happens, I would highly caution choosing Express Script as a career path.  They still have some fantastic managers and a new CEO so there is hope.

Phil

review_title: Express Scripts is Not a Bad Place to Work
job_title: Resolution Team Lead in Dublin, OH
pros: I love the fast-paced challenging environment.  If you work hard and remain consistent in your efforts you will be promoted.  ESI offers opportunities to employees with experience and having a degree is not required to work your way up.  I like that they prefer to promote from within and value practical job experience within the company.  The environment is one of fairness and equal opportunity and all of the supervisors and managers that I have worked with have been very approachable and quick to help when a problem arises.
cons: It is difficult for some to get used to having your schedule micro-managed down to the minute as is the case with entry level positions.  For positions which require the individual to field phone calls 8 hours a day, it can be very stressful and sometimes emotionally draining.  You are the sounding board for people who are affected by corporate decisions which often affect their health, decisions that you may or may not agree with personally and are often subjected to wishing there was more that you could do to help.

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Las Vegas, NV
pros: Good pay $18.96.  Great medical benefits, vision, dental. Tuition reimbursement.  Good support from management. Flexible work schedule.  Worked 10 hour split shifts which was wonderful for work/life balance.
cons: Top of pay scaled was reduced from $18.96 to $16.00 per hours which is a reduction of $2.96 per hour.  Would still be working there if pay wasn't docked and everyone working onsite was eliminated.  What they offered was a work at home model with the reduction in pay with some major conditions that were not workable.  They required you to pay for an independent dedicated high speed line for their equipment.  The room where you would work couldn't have  any other computers.  That was not feasible since my work room is where I keep all of my computers!

review_title: Not a bad job if you can tolerate the lack of proper management.
job_title: General Warehouse Associate in Whitestown, IN
pros: Great benefits! Excellent job opportunities. Great hours with minimal overtime. Overtime is typically voluntary. 6 paid holidays per year on top of paid time off!
cons: Lack of communication between shifts. Little or no room to grow with the company. ESI tends to prefer hiring from outside rather than promoting from within. Little to no accountability.

review_title: If you like healthcare and live in STL this is a great employer
pros: Fast paced roles. Hard working people. Intellectually challenging (in some/ many roles).  Going places- I believe we will always grow and overcome market challenges. People seem passionate about the place and serving clients and members. In my department, we work hard and hit deadlines but so have flexibility.  New CEO driving a real culture change with emphasis on growing people, training and development, candor, organic growth.
cons: Very large- you as a person can get lost. They don't yet have great cross department talent management practices but I hear that is a new focus.  Hierarchical leadership style but that's changing to be more flat under Tim. Some silos and lack of alignment between competing objectives but again I see that changing.

pros: No pros what so ever
cons: Everything was wrong, glad they were bought

pros: Decent PTO...when you can use it...Pay for college...although you will work so much, you won't have time to go. That's about it
cons:
Everything! Company will say "you're luck you have a job, we can replace you at any time." Mandatory OT started 4 years ago, and we were told it would last 3 months. Not only is it STILL going, it is MORE hours of mandatory OT. Salaried employees are told "you are salaried, we can make you work as much as we want." As a salaried person, you could be asked (told) to work extra days, and if you want to take a day off later, you still have to use PTO, even though you just put in 60 hours or more last week.
Basically, the company doesn't care a bit about employees, no such thing as work/life balance.
Turnover is ridiculous, due to all issue above, and management states that they "can't figure out why employees are not happy" - their words! And they have the gall to send lower management to classes on retaining employees. But when you tell them the reasons why the turnover rate is so high, you are ignored. Basically, nobody lasts more than about 3 years, either you get fed up and leave, or get fired.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: Work at home. Not the work load, the inept management who doesn't know what they are doing. This includes local direct management as well as upper management. It is a job that is all.
cons: Too many to list. Let's start with no work life balance. People working 70 hour weeks to get a Target rating. Management not having a clue. Micromanaging you for no point. This isn't being used for anything useful. Wasteful meetings with no point.. Yes, they 'care' about employees as I've heard. Caring to demote people, fire people for the good of the company. Cut salaries and give no raises. Hire cheap contractor labor from foreign lands that could care less about the company and the patients that we service. They also waste my time because I either have to fix what they don't know how to do or I have to deal with their stupidity just to get my job done.  That isn't caring about the employee.

pros: They do allow virtual offices, which is a plus for someone who doesn't like office living.  ESI does not require a lot of travel, unless you're client facing.  In that case, travel may be anywhere from 10-30% depending upon the client.
cons: It's a club - and you're either in it, or not.  Over the years, I have found that the opportunities are good, but not always accessible to everyone.  Management tended to keep those close to them that were friends - others were hard pressed to find a true direction.  I enjoyed my time at ESI tremendously - but all I can say is that CYA is the mantra.

review_title: Insane place to work for sure
job_title: Project Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great benefits, plenty of PTO, good bonus when you get it. Decent, caring co-workers. Great resume builder for future ex-express scripts careers.
cons:
Forced ranking (calibration) is the worst. Managers have to rank employees 20% Stretch (full bonus, merit increase), 70% Target (smaller bonus, smaller merit), and MUST put 10% at threshold (no bonus, no raise). Even if you're have all excellent performers. You manager must debate your worth against others in your salary level, with other managers who know nothing about you but have a say in your ranking. They dredge up things from years ago to "prove" a person is not worthy. Because of constant mgmt changes, little historical knowledge is retained so these stories get inflated. Lord of the Flies esque. 

Long hours, little "thanks" from management. Sr managers don't have a clue how the department works. Lots of busy work.

review_title: If you are a part of the elite upper, upper management, you got it made. Everyone else, not so much.
pros:
*It is better than having no job at all.
*401K and ESPP
*The people I work with make my day enjoyable.

**Based on the reviews I have read, ESI is not high on anyone's list.
cons:
*ESI does not want to pay lower-level people a competitive wage.
*Those of us on the frontlines are treated with disrespect and condescension.
*ESI seems to believe in having one person do the jobs of 5 people.
*ESI wants "quality", but does not want to pay for quality.
*Committees are formed to create bogus morale boosters; however, the activities are geared towards upper management! (Now, how does that make sense?)

pros: None...really.  Maybe casual dress.
cons: If you are a Pharmacist, don't walk...run!!  I left for ethical reasons.  They measure your productivity and if you can't process 100+ prescriptions/hour, you will not meet your metrics.  The plus in the 100+ is not small, either...120-140+ is more like it..  They divide the work into  buckets - Dr Call, Verification, Drug Interaction and your metric depends on what function you are performing.  If you reject one for concerns about the dose or a drug interaction, etc you don't "get credit" so it's actually more like 200/hr.  All kinds of games are played.  There is NO WAY an ethical Pharmacist can meet his or her professional obligations under those circumstances, so I left.  It was my only option because the numbers were only increasing.  It is DISTURBING and I don't know why the boards of pharmacy in the states where they operate aren't doing anything about this.  There's all kinds of things that go on in that company.  If a patient has gotten isosorbide mononitrate (Imdur) for the last 5 years and the dr writes for isosorbide dinitrate 1QD, don't question it...send it.  There are far worse examples, but I know I was spoken to about referring that one for md call.

review_title: If you have any other choice, don't work here
pros: This company is a good introduction to phone based client services. They train you fairly well how to use the systems and interact with customers. Pay is decent for someone just coming into the job market.
cons: Nobody in management or even supervisors are willing to listen to any ideas on how things could be run better. There is no life work balance, many people quit after our last shift bid (usually because they had younger kids and didn't want to stay till 9pm). You never know when your schedule is going to change or what it will be after the change, Office politics reins supreme here, everything is spread through the grapevine, both personal and business related topics. DO NOT JOIN THIS COMPANY AS A TEMP (this is what I did and they told us 90 days from the end of training would be when we were to be hired.... well that turned into 7 and half months).

review_title: The Yang and Yin experience all in one place...Medco the Good and ESI the not so good
pros:
-  There are still some good, talented people around
-  If you are a person who doesn't take many sick days, then you can accrue some extra vacation time
cons:
- If you are a former Medco person, progression in the company can be limited
- barely controlled chaos
- treated as a resource, not as an employee
- it can be very tough to get needed changes pushed through without much, much effort
- People have turned into silos....basically they hide and don't share information, since their job could be at risk or they can be replaced with someone cheaper.

pros: Horrible pay would not recommend
cons: SteadY income good to have.

job_title: Patient Service Representative in Las Vegas, NV
pros: There are no pros for this company.
cons: This place sucks and will continue to.

pros: This company offers a free  onsite cafeteria meal as an employee appreciation once  a year?,  free parking?,
cons: High turnover of employees and supervisors at Tempe .  The company does not care if the elderly cannot access their information via computer; therefore elderly call in extremly upset and cannot get their medication. LOW WAGES, they badger you by coming to your desk with snacks for you to buy so you do not get up from your desk, metrics keep changing to make it difficult for employees to maintain or reach, bathrooms are always disfunctional, they do not like to hear suggestions from lower level employees and if they do give someone a chance to speak and its a good suggestion management will use the suggestion as their own, their tracking system of sending out letters is not functional which causes letters to be sent multiple times and upsetting the customers and double work for the employees; there is always a shortage of work and they will badger you to take your vacation time and when a holiday comes up and you do not have the vacation time available its the ones who have been there the longest who get to take the time off.

review_title: If you recommend this job to a friend  they might not be your friend after that.
pros: Pay about Average for the job so if  average pay is good for you might want to work here  Some of the best people I have ever works with. They are going to a 4 day 10 hour day  but its going to a 7 day work week and as of now we don' t  have the people to do it . 401k is average, Health insurance is middle of the road,
cons: A business run by Larry , Moe, and Curley . .   The company seems to be adrift in not knowing what they need to do to run a business,  If you like working with a company that never tell you all the info about whats going on come here and get a job. if you take Meds you will find it cheaper on some to  get them at Walmart then Here

review_title: Mostly a rat race that will consume your life - with a few hidden gems
pros:
- A few departments left that offer a challenging, fast paced work environment
- The plus side to everyone being over employed is that you get to work alongside very skilled people
-health benefits are terrific, time off is decent (3 weeks for new employees, increases after 2 yrs)
cons:
Most departments are reactive rat cages that work their employees till they drop, and then fire them for dropping.
As a result the work environment sucks... very few are happy to be at work.
I've worked in two different departments - one was a larger department that was living hell - treated like a machine, forced to do shady/unethical work, etc. Now working in a different department that is nearly too good to be true; very challenging, great people to work with - by in large, a positive experience is not the usual one here at ESI, but they do exist - I'm living proof of both.

pros: EXTREMELY rewarding work! The Oncology TRC is full of people that care about the quality of their work and the patients that they serve.
cons: Everything is based on how much work you do and how fast you can get it done. Sometimes quality can suffer to keep up company quotas. Upward mobility is available in the company, if you fit the profile. The company has policies in place for inclusion, but the feel as if they are only "guidelines" at the Whitestown location, if used at all. Even if you ask, no explanations are given if you are passed on a promotion or what could you do different the next time. Titles are passed out and taken away at will.

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Tempe, AZ
pros: I couldn't find any pros while working for Express Scripts.
cons: If you don't mind be treated like a drone, a beast-of-burden, a cog and above all, a nobody then Express Scripts is for you! I mean, they'll use jargon such as "collaboration", "mutual respect" to (or try) convey a environment which foster's personal growth and opportunities, but in reality, they're just empty, hollow trite sentiments which gives illusion of those ideals which they purport to live up to. At Express Scripts, the way that you move up is not by what you know it's by who you know. Favoritism and incompetence is rife with no accountability and A typical day consist of you utilizing an archaic, inefficient interface taking call after call from disgruntled patients, doctor's offices and pharmacies who speak to you in a perfunctory manner to the point you were less than human and that's from the external clients! The internal clients, your peers (CphT, RPh's and nurses) were even WORSE, and this, all the while you're supposed to have a pleasant disposition at ALL times. There's attendance policy, but it's subjective, PTO is ungenerous and it literally takes an act of Congress to get any time off. Express Scripts is a surly, toxic nasty place and if you value your dignity and sanity then you really need to avoid THIS company, at all cost!

review_title: My Overall Job Experience.. Company Name was Medco until right after I left the Company.
job_title: Cust Ser Representative Work At Home in Charlotte, NC
pros: I had Supervisors who sincerely respected me and genuinely cared about me as a person.
cons: Professional and financial growth was next to nothing. I found that it profoundly effected my enthusiasm for my job. When I interviewed I distinctly asked if there was room for promotion and growth and was blatantly lied to. I did not want to join a company where I would be stuck in a rut but that is exactly what happened and not because I was not talented enough but I would have to relocate to Florida to do so. That was not the original information given to me in the interview.

review_title: Nurse Clinician RN (PBM prior auth dept)
pros: The work I did got boring, very repetitive, but enjoyable, easy, and stress free.
cons: Management is HORRIBLE. They lie, talk down to you, and act like they are in junior high. I cannot stress enough not to work in that department. Management will have 1:1 meetings with you and will gossip about it later to employees not holding a management role. They ask for opinions and suggestions but if you speak up, you are questioning your supervisor which you should not do. Then watch out. You are a target. That happened to me and I was moved to sit right in front of my manager. I am not a complainer. I am a hard worker who was striving to do my best and was going above and beyond. Employees are not at all valued. I was also told I couldn't eat lunch at my assigned time anymore, and it was getting changed due to "business needs" when there were 88 other employees on my team and I did not have the role of answering phones or anything. She wanted me to eat lunch alone at a time when no one else was scheduled to go to lunch. If you take a job there, hopefully all the bad managers have been weeded out after turning them into Human Resources.

job_title: Senior Intervention Technician in Tempe, AZ
pros:
The starting pay is better than average
The benefits are decent
The location is convenient
Most of the low level employees are nice and great to work with
cons:
Policies that set you up to fail
Incompetent IT department, HR department, management, & supervisors (the less competent you are the further you will go)
Outdated technology (some of the technology is so outdated it's not being taught in schools any more)
It's not about what you know it's all about who you know
Infinite compassion for the customers but none for the employees
An adherence to the policies so rigid that they don't take life into consideration (ex. traffic, sick children, etc.)
Poor communication with employees and between departments
Inaccurate tracking system for productivity and accuracy
Poor advancement opportunities
Poor annual/merit raises
Very patronizing environments
Employees are penalized for everything, even for preforming their assigned job function
No way to dispute inaccuracies in your error reports
Very inflexible scheduling

review_title: They should be ashamed of their company
job_title: Production Clerk in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Earn time off through PTO immediately...but it is difficult to use when you want to.
cons: Pay is awful.  "ESI Way" is hypocritical.  Policies change weekly.  Standard Operating Procedures are non-existant.  This obsession with lean manufacturing is pointless when management cannot even say "hi" when walking past the employees who are making the millions for them.  Management has zero social skills, see above.  Not a window in the place.  Customers are really not "our patients", we just fill their prescriptions.  As an employee, I have had the worst time getting my prescriptions filled correctly or in a timely manner.  The only reason I stay is for the miniscule paycheck until the economy opens up and can get out of this place.

review_title: They are not a customers focus company
job_title: Senior Intervention Technician in Whitestown, IN
pros: Some of the best people I have ever worked with,  Average pay  average benefit. Easy to get a job cause people come and go all the time if you have the skill  they thinks they need now
cons: Worse Hr Dept I have had 30 years of working , they are clueless on normal Hr needs  of the employees. You dont real have any one to talk to Just a big online dept that never really helps you get the answer you are looking for.  This is not a team effort place to work every area thinks they are the most inportant and the managemant does their best to keep everyone from trying to work together.

review_title: Slow, Painful, fall from being a market leader
pros: PBM industry is constantly changing and is an interesting place to be.
cons: Constant reorganizations without solving the route cause.  Extreme short sided decision making/lack of leadership has dragged the company down.

pros: The 401K match plan and low cost of medical benefit plans available to employees.  There are some great people who work for this company.  Unfortunately, none of them are in leadership positions to make the impact this company needs to remain relevant among the competition.
cons:
No work life Balance
Poor direction from leadership
Employee attrition due to unbalanced workloads and responsibilities between departments
No accountability from internal teams
Deplorable work culture with little to no recognition and leadership by management at any level

review_title: I'm not sure which company it is ESI or Accredo???
pros: 401k, PTO, day shift after a year if you're lucky, tuition reimbursement and sometimes great coworkers. And there's job stability if you keep quiet and stay 'under the radar'.
cons: Management is deplorable. Supervisors are bred from former incompetent supervisors and their concern for micromanaging instead of quality training is why the Indy location is subpar. If you're not in the "Mommy Club" or a brown-noser, you're not chosen for 'special projects' that are a complete waste of company time. The team morale is non-existent, unless you want to do frivolous things such as pitch-ins and buy cake-pops. And the training consists of incompetent employees training other incompetents. Even supervisors aren't trained in the basic processes.

review_title: MY OWN EXPERIENCE WORKING FOR EXPRESS SCRIPTS
job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Indianapolis, IN
pros:
-Benefits are decent
-You're earning income -w/ the potential for bonuses (paid holidays)
-6 hours and a few minutes of PTO every two weeks are earned
cons:
EVERYTHING ELSE!!! (for me working here was just straight up miserable)
-calls are BACK TO BACK TO BACK TO BACK
-makes other call center jobs seem like a walk in the park
-they carry on about their "express way values" - but its BS
-training was terrible- ONLY because it does not prepare you for  ANYTHING you'll go through on the phones-only thing I really took out of training was how to navigate the system
-not paid enough for the way you're treated and spoken to on the phones (called out of name, threatened, and all other sorts of discriminating communication)
-they expect life to not happen , so if anything comes up you better hope you have some pto saved up bc you'll get an occurrence 
-team leads don't help like they try to make it seem like they do, just there for coaching thats about it
-A LOT of system issues  & they still want you taking calls, even when you can't help
-other people in management aren't really any help either 
-would not recommend for parents or anyone in school -because it's just ONE BIG HEADACHE ! 
-different departments are CLUELESS to their job
to some it up the job is NOT for everybody

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Saint Marys, GA
pros: You get to work indoors.
cons:
PCAs are treated like cattle. The mindless few who put up with the crap (they consider it better than flipping burgers) get promoted to team leaders having never been in a supervisory position before. They constantly change the pay structure when it starts costing them too much money.  As far as customer service, there is none. PCA's are encouraged to all but lie to people expecting their medications in the mail. And Express Scripts sends medications even when customers tell them to stop or to send no more. You have to be brain dead to use their mail order service. The reason it's cheaper is because they don't use brand medications even when customers say they don't want generics, whoops I forgot PCAs are not allowed to call them that..they must refer to them as "alternative" medications.  At the first of the year (2013) they screwed up thousands of customers benefits so people would go to the drug store to pick up their medication only to be told they had no coverage. Everything they do is to attempt to show big insurance companies they are responsible. 
Blue Cross should plant some moles so they could see exactly what REALLY goes on.

review_title: Rated top 3 in the worst companies I've ever worked for
job_title: Project Manager in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: My co-workers are awesome people- that's it, nothing else.
cons: Legacy Medco was head & shoulders above ESI.  Since the merger, it's been disastrous, I've been with ESI since the merger and see how they run their company.  I gave it a chance, I truly did.  However, ESI hires the cheapest staff they can find, their management hires in St Louis are a joke. They don't have long range plans, they implement changes and don't plan how it will affect the downstream areas.  The downstream areas are confused by the work you do....It's just silo after silo.   It's disorganized and poorly run.  Nothing ESI does is properly managed or thought out. Company is so 15 years ago, the technology they use is a joke, their business practices are from 1992.....it's like stepping into a time machine when you visit headquarters in St. Louis.  It's so sad when I come to the office in NJ, remembering how great Medco was, so innovative with lots of opportunity.   Understanding it's a business and we're here to make money, this company is so poorly run from top to bottom.   The benefits that were offered for 2014 were a joke!

pros:
Non-typical pharmacist job duties
Several different departments to work in
Standard schedules
cons: No promotional opportunities for pharmacists without an MBA. Almost all management positions are filled externally with no training or career development for current staff. Very numbers driven for employee performance, which creates poor customer service. For a mail order pharmacy, you would think pharmacists would be more involved in the operating and management processes. Pharmacists are not well respected and are considered just entry level staff. It’s amazing how a Doctorate degree taking 6 plus years is considered entry level when the VP only has a 2 year MBA degree.

review_title: The company I worked for was bought by ESI in a merger; and while I like ESI, I miss my old job.
job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Express Scripts offers a strong level of stability.  Because it is PBM, the health insurance benefits are inexpensive and provide a lot of coverage.  With several locations throughout the US and Canada, if you are looking to relocate, that is always an option and HR is very helpful with that.  There are also many opportunities for advancement or to move laterally to another department.
cons: You don't get a lot of holidays off, and PTO can be pretty difficult to come by.  Also, they are very particular about metrics and do not seem concerned with work-life balance.  They say they are, but really are not.  Also, this company made billions and stands to earn more if the Medco merger is successful, but employees will not receive a bonus and I'm sure any pay increases will be minimal.

pros: Health benefits are still OK, although they used to be better.  There is opportunity to move up the ladder; but I urge you to think twice before doing so. The tallest blade of grass is always the first to get cut.
cons: Way too much emphasis is put on numbers and 6-S.  Management creates a stressful work environment, then scolds employees for having "bad attitudes". Your worth is directly related to your metrics. The company considers themselves totally successful as long as the bottom line looks good no matter what it takes to get there. Employee satisfaction is never a consideration; employees are pawns. Results of internal surveys are always negative but nothing is ever done about it. There are no benefits associated with tenure. Time off for holidays is decided by a lottery drawing. Who does that??

review_title: Why so many fake reviews in July? Painfully obvious and very unprofessional/tacky. Job seeker BEWARE.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Post merger NONE with the exception of the 401k and the dozen or so good employees left.
cons:
This just goes to show you what kind of company we are dealing with. ESI gets voted the WORST co. to work for in the US after being rated second worst two years in a row, and then a bunch of bizarre 4 and 5 star ratings begin to appear on GD. Reviews are all posted around mid-July and all written in the same sentence structure. Does ESI really think people are that clueless??

It's obvious that ESI can no longer attract good talent, and most of the talented people have already left running for their lives. The word is out there. Nobody wants to work for a company like this, especially when there are so many better organizations out there without a horrendous reputation. If you value life, and your well being do NOT even bother applying to ESI. I can't even to begin to describe the things I experienced while I was there, and wouldn't wish it on my worst enemy's dog. A very scary environment IMHO.

review_title: Work here if you enjoy being S$%^ on daily by some of the worst leaders in business!
job_title: IT Professional in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Paid time off is very generous.  Decent benefit package.
cons:
Leadership that manages up, not down
Only concerned with the bottom line and keeping stock price up at the expense of employee work life balance.
Sales makes unrealistic promises to potential clients and then IT is forced to deliver by working 60-70 hour weeks.
Bonus only to management level and then that is even at manager's discretion.
Instead of downsizing the right and fair way, management has been instructed from on-high to put a large number of GOOD people on a performance improvement plan.  The goal is to get them to quit or if they don't, they are in the pool to be "fired" when the company needs to cut heads.  In all my years in business, I have never seen such a disgusting display of zero integrity.

job_title: Call Center Supervisor in Mason, OH
pros: Ability to work from home, decent pay and benefits, casual dress, good PTO accrual rate, no weekends, schedule flexibility if you need to leave early or start later
cons: Upper management makes decisions constantly, frequent layoffs make employees always nervous about job security, not enough training when changes occur, contradictory information in different systems make it difficult to know which information is correct, systems slow and can be down for hours-not good when you have to catch up later and asked to work weekends to make up for it.  Also, bed bug history in Mason.  They do try to control with treatments, but do not advertise what the "routine spraying" is for.

review_title: Bad departments in a good company
pros: Abilitu to transfer to other lovations throught the us, Flexible attendance policy, Competitive pay
cons: I have worked in the Patient Access Department for four years. For the longest I believed that my hard work would one day be noticed. Instead the harder you are a worker the more you're used and abused. Supervisors and manger will let you  cheat the company  away with murder as long as you are willing  to do their job for them. I know because am that favorite. Favoritism and lack of professionalism  is unbelievable. I see people's  personal  and medical life get exposed amongst management just for laughs and it just isn't  right. There has been employees that have  taken issues  to HR and the  HR rep went back to the accused manager and threw  the rep under  the bus. And the Sr manager over the department even told us employees that we are replaceable. They lie and tell u that if u constantly meet production and quality you can go work from home but when it comes to thst time they tell you that the "budget " doesn't cover the equipment. I have been 1st on the work from home list since May2014. It's sad. I could go on and on. Do not work here unless you want to be on antidepressants!!!

job_title: Senior Production Clerk in Saint Louis, MO
pros: PTO..paid time off..earned every pay period. Can accumulate up to 4 weeks the first year.  You will need it all to keep your sanityl
cons:
Pay is horrible.  Standing on concrete floors for 10 hour shifts is barely bearable.  Jobs and work functions are extremely boring.  If they could get away with training monkeys to do the jobs I did, they would to save money.

For a pharmacuetical company, their health benefits are poor.  their pharmacuetical benefits are a ripoff.  They force you to get your prescriptions filled through mail order at $20 per generic script while I can get it for $10 at a local grocery store.  Ripoff.  If you no longer take a medication but it is on the auto refill program and they send it to you, you have to pay for it.  Nor returns, no refunds.  They are stealing from people.  

I took the job when it was the only thing going three years ago.  The experience has only proven to me that corporate greed is alive and well.

pros: Good people in all divisions  and levels who do care and work hard.   Bonus decent dependent on where you fall. Stock good if you get it. PTO decent
cons: Benefits, holidays stingy and geared to a manufacturing environment.  Culture of fear, punishment and politics of who you know, what location you work.  Want inexperienced and obedient folks who question nothing and do meaningless projects. Who you have favor with is all that matters but no real loyalty except for a few.   Efforts to suggest interest in change like surveys and rewards are superficial and insignificant to the larger issues. Not really interested in honest feedback so people don't speak the truth

pros: Large company with competitive Benefits
cons:
Worst company I have ever worked for! Sr. Leadership does not care about staff. Everyone is disposable from Sr. VP to Warehouse staff. 

Visits to local sites from Sr. Leadership are rare. If they do happen, rarely is anytime spent with line level supervisors and below. In fact they will walk right by them without even saying good morning as if they are all beneath them. Instead they meet with Directors and above then after each visit they start a massive push to eliminate employees. 

Constant push to eliminate those 50 and above to replace with younger cheaper and less experienced staff.

The arrogance of this leadership team is beyond describable. If the failing idea was their idea they will stick with it until the stock holders scream mercy, and then they will point fingers in every direction and start cutting heads. If the idea comes from below the VP level it will be humored at best until VP level presents the idea as their own. 

This senior leadership team is absolutely disgusting

review_title: Would NOT recommend this company to anyone!!!
job_title: Pharmacy Technician in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Really can't think of any pros when it comes to Express Scripts.
cons: Where shall I start? Too many Chiefs and not enough Indians. Raises are based on your popularity, if you're tied with a peer when it comes to your raise, whoever is better likes gets the highest raise. Express Scripts WILL NOT give the top raise to every employee who deserves and/or earned it. If you do get a raise, it's only pennies. And as far the bonuses go, again it depends if they like you or not. The better you're liked, the higher the bones. They don't believe in giving everyone the top raise and that is coming from a supervisors mouth. What I've noticed as far as promotions go, African Americans and Middle Eastern people are the ones being promoted. I could go on and on, but I won't. I'm not a bitter former employee. I put in my time and left on great terms. Just not a place to retire from. I would rather clean bathrooms then work at ESI. Glad my prison sentence is over.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
-fast paced organization with endless opportunities to get involved (not for everyone, but if you thrive in this kind of environment you will do well)
-admirable mission as an organization- servicing 85M Members means we have a large impact within the healthcare industry
-bright, enthusiastic employees- always encounter people who want to help and get involved
-opportunities- if you have ideas or ways to make improvements, teams are willing to listen
-flexibility- depends on which team you join, but overall the culture is one that is flexible to support your scheduling needs
-evolving culture- moving away from focus on M&A and now heavily focused on organic growth; will take time, but you can feel the shift in valuing employees
cons:
-forced ranking (discontinuing this in 2017)
-negative image in the market place, but one that will hopefully shift over time

job_title: Call Center Representative in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Benifits and pay are very good
cons: Management andnew hire commuications are poor and not employee friendly .

job_title: Accounting Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good dining options at corp. office
cons: Corporate drones being forced to take on larger and larger loads

pros: New Environment, interesting process, n/a
cons:
High Stress
Management unable to understand workload
Contracts have no growth

review_title: NOT A TOP COMPANY TO WORK FOR
pros:
Fixed schedule
Benefits are outstanding covering medical, dental, rx, vision
employee discounts with selected retailers
cons:
Advancement opportunity is limited
Training and promoting is obsolete
Annual reviews are brief and at the managers discretion if you will even get a raise 
Stingy with bonuses, salary, and perks
NOT as family oriented of a company as they portray , could be a lot better for a muli-million dollar company
PTO approval is at the managers discretion, even though you earned it
Employees do not have voice within the company without filtering through management

review_title: Opportunities available, but constant change and long hours.
pros: For me, there was a lot of opportunity for growth as part of recent acquisitions and a large range of projects that needed to be filled with employees eager to develop.
cons: The growth brought a ton of change, org re-alignments, etc. that often times didn't stick for long. As a result you have a lot of confusion on where the company was headed, who worked under which work stream, etc. yet at the same time you'd almost expect things to change once again. Much is the result of the Medco acquisition and company integration but still did create a lot of inconsistency. Also, depending on your role expect that you may have to put in a LOT of overtime to get things done (whether you are salary or not).

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Port Saint Lucie, FL
pros: Great place to gain experience but at least for me, it was not a career. I did not say growing up I want to sit in a cubicle talking to miserable old people all day that don't understand you and don't care that you are trying to help them as best you can with the very limited tools that you have access to.
cons: The people on the phones are the worst part of the job IMO. They're rude and often times disgusting to speak with. You're bonus incentive is based off their biased opinion on how you handled the call. I say biased because they can be mad about things that are absolutely out of your control and then rate your service bad because they're angry they didn't get their way. You can't make everyone happy. Sometimes they have to have a little homework and they get mad because you couldn't do everything for them. Also Not having enough access to tools to help.

pros: You do get to work form home, which saves money on commuting, gas money, work clothing, and office drama.  When it is slow, they offer VTO-unpaid time off the phones.
cons: Everything else-the pay is $12 an hour, which is way too low for the broad knowledge you have to learn, the patience to deal with irate callers, and the back to back calls all day.  After training, it's all about metrics-they track your use of any personal time, how closely you adhere to breaks and lunches, and how often you call for assistance with questions.  It is very Big Brother.  And no matter how rude a customer is, you are not allowed to hang up on them or offer a supervisor transfer.  Too much stress for too little money, in my opinion.

pros: Very profitable business model, stock seems to keep going up, pay was good, and that is about all that I can say.
cons: As much as they talk of collaboration being the key, I didn't see it.  Aggressive ThirtySomethings were very highly valued, while anyone with more than 10 years with the company was pushed aside regardless their abilities, history of collaboration success.  For eager young professionals, it is a great place to learn, because everyone needs to attend the school of hard knocks and at ESI one has the opportunity to sink or swim or burn out.  Good luck.

job_title: Director of Technology in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Technology organization is going through a reset and a change in mindset from constant acquisitions to improving technology and productivity.  Having come from a large global company that was ranked in the top 5 place to work in the US I was a little skeptical of the transformation talk during my interviews.  I made the move as I have faith in the the Sr leadership team making long term investments and understanding user and employee experience and how that effects productivity and happiness.  A lot of people can make a great impact here and feel empowered to help change happen and continue to help the company grow.
cons: I haven't found any major con, there is a lot of improvement opportunities that is going through the motions of employee empowerment and various individuals seeing something and knowing that it can be done better.

pros: The reward of knowing I'm helping people obtain the medications that are needed; assisting pharmacists, adjusters & prescribers with the proper care of their patients/clients.  Educating people can be very rewarding.
cons: Dealing with lazy people that assist as little as possible(my coworkers or others). Pharmacies that refuse to call to assist patients with medication authorizations and doctor's offices that refuse to fax/call in prescription for their patients or insist on a fee for faxing presciptions.

review_title: Very high turnover, leaving the company without experienced employees.
job_title: Automation Service Technician in Whitestown, IN
pros: The work is not difficult.  If you are good friends with the right supervisor, you can earn promotions quickly.
cons: Low hourly pay unless your a pharmacist, not many holidays off, tenure does not earn respect/render achievements, poor health care plan, penalized for being sick (doctors note doesn't stop you from receiving negative points on attendance), many changes in management and human resources team members caused mass confusion since nobody is experienced enough to know what the rules are.  Lunch is not paid, no cafeteria on 2nd shift, mcdonalds is only alternative is you dont bring lunch.  No matter the weather, the site does not close. (blizzards for example)  Most of these changes occurred after Express Scripts acquired Medco, this information is true for the Whitestown, In location.   Wall Street named Express Scripts 2nd worst company to work for in the nation.

job_title: Senior Eligibility Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good health benefits, vacation time, decent compensation and great co-workers.
cons:
Express Scripts (ESI) used to be a nice place to work. The company was very employee oriented and we were able to have fun while still getting work accomplished. The morale began sliding dramatically as department management changed due to being over stressed and overworked. Outsourcing became more popular which in turn brought layoffs. The fun employee appreciation activities stopped at a company level and care for employees completely went out the window. Anyone who has worked at ESI for any amount of time (at least in Eligibility) is completely deflated and in fear of losing their job. There is absolutely no work/life balance either. When I left ESI, I was working a minimum of 60 hours every week while being a salary employee (no overtime pay) and absolutely no appreciation for the extra work.
Cons: no work/life balance, lack of care for employees (feel like just a number), terrible training (for new & existing employees, lack of job knowledge by management, extremely high stress

review_title: Have to thrive in a fast changing environment
pros: Fast paced, ever changing, lots of opportunity to step outside of your normal function if you show initiative, HR is good at screening out jerks which means if you're an adult you will rarely come across a mean person.  I found that I thrive in this type of environment. It's not for everyone. As a side note my experience has to do with operations. I know nothing about the call center side of the company so don't relate my positives and negatives to that side of the fence. I've heard it's drastically different though.
cons: If you can't roll with the tide and not let things slide you won't do well. If you like change you will float, if you don't you will drown.  After the hiring process HR is pretty much invisible and getting worse. You have to except the fact that they are there for the company and not for you.

review_title: Was once a good place to work, but has gone down hill fast
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Bloomington, MN
pros:
very good salary and good bonus
Good benefits
good group of employees (what is left of them)
cons:
Out sourcing resulting in inferior quality.
This move, which was to save money, is resulting in huge increases in project hours, increased employee hours, and inferior work.  This is causing delays and issues for clients and the business.

Senior management - lack of ethics, interested only in short term goals and profits, no respect for employees.  
They have admittedly perverted the performance system for their own use to force out employees instead of paying severance.  They use a popularity system, commonly called calibration, to rank employees irregardless of performance.  They intent ally cause employees stress, uncertainty and concern to force them to quit so they make their head count and get their bonuses.  They have implied that good quality is "just good enough" and "we need to get it done to meet our dates and we'll fix it later" 
Total disregard for the "Express Way".  They have thrown away Ethics and Mutual Respect.

pros: Living in a small town without a car makes it very hard to find employment.  If you are trying to get an education those benefits are good, the benefit deductibles and copays are not great.  You have to be available to work every holiday unless you take vacation.
cons: What a horrific place to work, pennies for raises, scheduled 2 weeks off vacation three months in advance to see a new grandchild on the opposite coast.  One week before it was time to go it was cancelled due to business needs.  Had to advise that I had paid for vacation rental and had to literally beg and plead for the time off.  Medco people make way more than ESI legacy so they are firing all of them.  No one knows what they are doing with the Medco merge, had to delay my son's funeral because no one knew who was handling the death benefits.  It took 2 weeks and 14 calls before one person sent me to the correct person at Medco.

job_title: Senior Pharmacy Tech in Tempe, AZ
pros: They provide competitive wages for pharmacy technicians. From what I understand, they pay more per hour than most pharmacies.
cons: It's very apparent that they do not value their employees. It doesn't matter to them what you accomplish, or what you sacrifice for the sake of the company. I'm convinced that you could be the highest achiever, and you could give them all of your working years, without even receiving a thank you in return. If you believe in working hard, do not get a job at Express Scripts, you'll only be casting your pearls to swine.

review_title: New employee training is very poor, along with a generally hostile work environment.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: ESI is a fast-paced, learn-as-you-go environment with no margin for error. Some people will thrive in this environment and others won't. If you like feeling that kind of pressure for 8+ hours a day then you will love working for this company.
cons: Entry level compensation is not comparable to other local call centers. ESI supports an extraordinarily poor training staff that is not skilled in teaching people with different learning styles and abilities. Schedules are very erratic which makes a work/home life balance impossible (however, that fact is made very clear during the interview process). Be warned, a hostile work environment is glaringly apparent between contingent, legacy, and new employees. That being the case, the aforementioned statements should not be surprising considering that ESI is merely a call center that handles prescription benefits for group insurance companies and its participants.

pros: There are some good points to this company, those being the current salary and health insurance. Our location is union and I suspect this is the only reason we enjoy these perks. Unfortunately that is seemingly where the pros end.
cons: No consistency in operations/policies, and managerial decisions rarely make sense. Time is often wasted being pulled into "huddles" where nothing is seemingly accomplished and the same things are being said every time like they are scripted. Training, is a joke. You are given a very rudimentary idea of how to do a job and then left to basically figure it out on your own. Don't rely on current operational procedures to remain consistent, as they will change and you will likely not be notified of this. There is also the "layoff factor". I realize that layoffs are a fact of life, especially when working in pharmaceuticals, but from what I've seen and read this factor is amplified to the extreme with this particular company. This can't be good for employee morale.

review_title: Company priority = PROFITS Employees and Clients are at the bottom of the list
pros: There are places to move within the organization if you know can figure out how to maneuver the politics. There are decent bonus incentives if you're on the right team.
cons: Medco merger was handled horribly and ESI took on more than they can handle. ESI laid off many of the tech support for the Medco operating systems they have taken on and have been unable to train ESI employees on the systems. Very poor planning of teams and unhappy employees due to "workhorse" mentality.

pros: Fairly flexible when it comes to pre-planning time off, plenty of support for work questions, those who struggle to meet their rates have plenty of access to guidance and tips to help them improve, the health care benefits are really good, the raises are pretty decent and yearly
cons: those who want to move up and become leaders seem to the ones that are "in" with those that are already leaders, too much popularity contest nonsense, too much office drama or office politics, too many stand up meetings (daily meetings for everyone), too much pressure to meet rates and not enough praise for QUALITY - they "say" quality is most important and then give better raises to those who produce the most volume instead. Lots of lies being told by leaders - too much gossip and two-faced behavior

review_title: Express Scripts - Eventually, they'll just hire robots
job_title: Data Entry in North Versailles, PA
pros: Decent pay, consistent hours, time off was flexible. Trainers were nice. Lots of VTO if you wanted to take it without any penalty (other than no pay).
cons: Very sterile environment, you're a number not a person. Daily huddles talked down to staff, made us feel stupid and inadequate. Always a threat that today could be your last day for who knows what reason. Work load is ridiculous, some queues you are expected to do 2-3 orders per minute and you are not allowed to make a single error. Of approx. 40 new hires, less than 10 made it through probation and were hired on as full time staff. I passed probation but quit shortly after due to the high stress environment. Workload was slowly being switched over to an automated process, anyways, so there didn't seem to be a lot of job security.

pros:
A Lot of paid time off
Very good benefits
Management knows everybody by name, even peons like us!
Regular performance reviews
Decent starting pay
cons:
No advancement unless you push for it
Lousy pay raises - difference in pay raise, between a great review and a bad review is 10 cents p/h!! Insulting! Why try harder for 10 cents p/h?
Boring at times - though no fault of the company
No raises or promotions if you have been written up for any infraction, no matter how trivial

pros: Work at home is an option.  Some great people really do work there. I get a package for leaving. Made me happy.
cons: No work life balance. It feels like a gang war between ESI and Medco employees.  They protect the people who used to work with them at their previous company whether they are qualified or not.  Project managers are more like analysts in some departments. Director wasted people's time with dumb assignments that added no value to the company.  Why would project managers be listening to 50 calls a day? Where they do that at? Express Scripts. Client needs are not the priority. Members are suffering due to inept processes that people either don't know how to fix or too prideful to fix since it was supposed to be a perfect system. New system is so flawed and so inflexible, it's pathetic. Expect you to work a ridiculous amount of hours with not even a thank you.

review_title: Top heavy company no training but great colleagues
job_title: Business Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Standard job benefits that are included in fortune 500. Easy interview and great colleagues. Excellent 401k match remote work freedom depending on manager however everything will be changing after Cigna takeover effective 2020. Only good for short term in these cases since it takes over a year to get used to the PBM business.
cons: Everything depends on your immediate manager which is middle management position and though my manager and colleagues were excellent the department itself was lousy with no training and very short sighted approach to problems. No opportunity for promotion or growth unless you switch departments. Lots of silos and middle management has a hard time dealing with it. Lack of fresh ideas and approaches in top management and you will see same people getting promoted year after year 😁 who are pals.

review_title: IT Management has lost focus, no longer values employees
pros:
Good salary& benefits
Was a very good company until 2009; perhaps sometime in 3-5 years, this will recycle?
cons:
The IT Management lost focus; employees no longer work together.
IT Management do not value the skills and knowledge of their staff; this is a complex industry and those in leadship positions are upward focused only.
A quick decision to remove very large percentage of IT development staff and replace with offshore staff has backfired, mostly because this was coupled with bringing in new management that lack leadership, or, believe that leadership involves throwing staff under the bus without due process and factual basis.  The problem began when when certain levels of management had a performance goal to reduce staff, then the breakdown of Integrity, Mutual Respect, Collaboration began.

review_title: If you want to work here you better like a job that sucks your soul dry and leaves you feeling empty
pros:
Well the pay is average.  you work with great people who for the most part all feel the same way.
Average benefits  with very small bonuses unless your in management then pay is below aveage.
Does have very clean bathrooms and a over priced lunch room.
cons:
We work in Whitestown  Indiana not Carmel get the town right. HR dept does not have a clue what's it doing most of the time and they keep hiring some real losers., I do love they way when I looked on here I see 5 star rating I wonder if they got the wrong company or  have a member of management  standing behind them as they enter the info.
Hope you like working 6 days a week cause they don't ever seem to get it right on how much each site is able to produce or have all sites operating at the same time or give you enough people to keep production moving

pros: Got paid every 2 weeks
cons: Liars.  Performance appraisal not based on individual performance, but on your performance rating against everyone else at your grade level. Only those with jobs having high visibility or a cost savings project receive rewards.  If you work in an internal support function, you have no chance of your efforts, no matter how great they might be, being recognized.  So incredibly tight with funding that many critical project needs are put on hold or canceled.  ESI uses lots of contractors because they can easily end the contracts without having to deal with severance or Cobra costs.  This again shows how little they are interested in their employees.  Having worked for many years in management prior to my company being bought by ESI, I was appalled at what I was being told to do.

review_title: Main consideration is dollars and cents and workers aren't either of those
pros: Salary seems competitive but then "dollars per actual hour worked"  is much lower.  I get the opportunity to lead people but only unofficially, as my bosses fear of being found out as unnecessary.
cons: Management' s whole ideology is "if there is a problem, make a fast but not well thought out decision".  If there is a problem with that decision, put a bandaid on it.  if the bandaid doesn't work, ask the tech guys to come up with a solution.  Said tech guys will then take so long to implement a solution(6 months-1.5 years), you forget about the initial issue.  You only know the solution was implemented when you realize the tech guys broke something else that was already working correctly.  But at the end of the day, no one is culpable and the guy at the bottom doing the actual work is the only one who now has to work harder to complete the same task, but with more steps and less time.

pros: Large company, many locations to move around  if desired. Great co-workers. A few great leaders that make you proud of where you work.
cons:
Large company, people are easily replaced 

A lot of nepotism within all departments of the company, a who you know depends on where and how high you go within the  company. 

Numbers on paper are more important than the patients they serve and the quality of the service given to the patient. 

Since merging with Medco there is a lot of confusion on who does what, what goes where, and how many people are actually needed to ensure patients and employees are satisfied, all about saving  money, paid so much for the merger to happen need to get some back. 

Lack of leadership from management within some departments 

HR doesn't look into any complaints or issues against managers  brought to them by employees, they will side with management without investigating even when it is told to them to be untrue.

review_title: Not for the Faint of Heart
pros:
The benefits are ok.
My individual team is really good people and worth coming to work for.
cons:
The job is grueling- the work is extremely varied and you spend a lot of time investigating information that doctors and other departments should have already provided.  

The emotional kickback is high- you are dealing with patients who are in pain- have drug addictions- parents of babies- telling them meds are denied or we screwed up a shipment. It can be heart-wrenching.

The management doesn't get it- they expect big numbers but it is completely luck of the draw whether you get accounts that can easily be completed or if they will take days or even weeks to resolve- which means it affects if you get a raise or bonus.

November through march is like a never ending hell week- accounts that never end, mandatory overtime, upset customers, upset management if you don't make your numbers.  The stress is very high.

review_title: Largest PBM, yet at or near bottom of PBM's to work for
pros:
Schedule- Awesome, pretty much a schedule to fit everybody.
Bonus- If you are top notch and exceed set rates as an RPh or Tech you WILL get rewarded at year end with good bonus as they do reward their top 25% performers well.
 Salary- Overall, no complaints here.
cons:
Trust in Upper Management- None. Easily the most corrupt and unethical upper management team I have ever worked for, and most likely in the entire PBM industry.
Competency of Upper Manangement- Severely lacking. They have tremendous trouble keeping clients due to the terrible service that is given. Beyond penny pinching when it comes to allowing their employees to attempt to take care of their customers. You do not have a good feeling about how your company services patients when you go home at the end of the day.

review_title: They say they care, but they really don't
pros: The pharmacy benefits management (PBM) industry is a very interesting and dynamic industry. You do learn a lot.
cons: Senior management's transparency is almost non-existent. They don't care about work-life balance. They are an internally-focused, nickel and dime organization that also pays St. Louis, MO wages across the country, meaning if you live on the West Coast or the East Coast, don't expect to get a salary that matches your area's cost of living for the amount of work they want you to do. The hierarchal culture and politics are ridiculous, and creates a lot of miscommunication and misunderstanding. The integrating between Express Scripts and Medco (my company who they bought out) has been an absolute nightmare. Top talent keeps walking out the door. The layoffs. It's just sad.

review_title: The worst place I have ever worked
pros: The benefit package and PTO. They give you lots of PTO but then you have a calendar to look at for future dates you can take and they are all blacked out so you cannot even use the time the give you. Such a JOKE.
cons: They cram too much material into 3 weeks and then throw you out on the floor to work in a sweat shop. No care for employees or patients. The only thing they care about are the quotas you have to meet. You sit at a cubicle, no phone, no contact with anyone. Just sit and pump out orders. If you have any type of stress or anxiety, this place will throw you over the top. Supervisors are rude, leads who are supposed to be there for support are rude. Don't waste your time, please run. If you need proof, watch how many times they are running Data Entry and Pharmacy Technician ads. I was in a class of 18 and only 1 person out of the whole class planned on staying there.

review_title: My tenure was disappointing due to the work culture of the organization
pros: If you work hard, produce results you are financially rewarded.
cons: The company owns you...they expect your job to be priority #1.  Even if you don 't want it to be, it has to be, as there is no way to keep up with the workload  if you take some days off.

review_title: Words cannot describe how bad it is
job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Tempe, AZ
pros: It's a paycheck that is the only positive there is
cons: Management keeps upping the standards. They continue to expect more and more from their techs and don't give us anything in return. They keep putting questionable policies into effect and when they are questioned about them all you get is the run around about them. They want the company to be your number one priority, not your family or other prior commitments. Forget your personal life if you work for this company, your personal life becomes this company. They initiate mandatory overtime, take away quarterly bonuses or when they decide to give them back, they cut them because you didn't give them the very best performance you could have. They expect you to work job functions above your pay level but NOT get paid for it even though there is plenty of your own work that needs to be done. There is a complete lack of communication between departments.

job_title: Customer Service Representative in Irving, TX
pros: Work@Home was the best perk, excellent pay, excellent paid time off and medical insurance benefits.  Line supervisors pursued professional customer service attributes be demonstrated at all times.  Customers were treated with respect and their concerns and issues were brought to an amicable resolution.
cons: Work@Home perk was removed and found as something not in keeping with a productive work environment, first signs of a mediocre small town corporate mentality.  Benefits and pay similar to a cheap WalMart store, with medical insurance that mimic Wal-Mart's plans.  Representatives treated as if they were taking catalog orders by phone, instead of providing excellent feedback, pharmaceuticals are not items of clothing!  Require much higher levels of attention to detail otherwise customers can be harmed physically.

review_title: Jack Welch Management Principals Have a Huge Downside to the Organization
pros: The generous management bonus structure.
cons: Senior Management has implemented Jack Welch Management principles:  The top 20 % get all of the raises, bonuses and perks and the bottom 10% are subject to strict discipline up to and including termination.   During my tenure at Express Scripts, I witnessed many collegues who were fired or laid off; much more so than any organization I was a part of.  Having seen this first hand myself, I felt as if the "Sword of Damocles" was hanging over my head every day I came to work.  This was very stressful for me; my family could see the toll that this stress was causing me.

pros:
If you have the particular skills for the projects they have going you can make a good income while you are there.  
Go in prepared to work hard with minimal support you will do fine.
cons:
Like many companies that have experienced massive growth over a short time, the company's culture does not match its present state.  It is like working at a Mom & Pop shop with all the added process of a major corp.  But "Mom" trumps policy all too frequently.
