The corporate values are just words on the wall .  Work/life balance for employees is a joke.  Contract employees are often paid well but treated like cattle.  Large numbers of people crammed into converted conference rooms way to small for the number of people

Not at all surprised to read reviews listing the company among worst place to work in St Louis

job_title: Pharmacy Technician IV Years, Accounts Receivable II Months in Austin, TX
pros:
Big Company
Great Health Benefits and Paid Time Off
Excellent Training
Some good & helpful people! (really depends on the location and department you work in)
cons:
Big Company
Rigid authoritarianism
Always coming up with more "guidelines" and "rules" for no ones benefit. Just because they can.
Don't put anything in your middle desk drawer! It must remain empty! All personal family photos have to be in the designated far right corner of your desk in the 2 square foot area.
Company has lost it's identity over the years, as many large successful companies do.
I like Cyborgs. Want to know what it feels like to be a robot?

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The Company has heard the feedback of the employees and has implemented changes, including a revamp of its performance management process, open forums with senior staff members, a new health and wellness program, improvements to our main facility in St. Louis, and work/life balance initiatives in many departments.  The CEO has made the company culture a top priority, and has repeatedly said that he wants to make Express Scripts a great place to work.  I feel supported in my job role and am optimistic about my development and future prospects.
cons: Meeting calendars are booked solid, all day, every day, leaving very little time during the day for actual work.  Sometimes I end up doing it before or after the usual work day, affecting work-life balance.

review_title: I am a management employee; so, I may have a different perspective than some of the hourly employees.
pros: Company is growing and always hiring.  New opportunities present themselves and there are several locations.  Company has decent benefits, has a community presence, and is linked to healthcare.
cons: Company does not recognize the 24-hour day.  Managers work day and night to get their work done.  It is almost impossible to go home without a laptop, blackberry, or some way of staying connected to work, even when on vacation.  Planning at the top level does not appear to happen.  Ther is no infrastructure, after all these years of operation.

review_title: They pride themselves on Integrity but I don't see it
job_title: IT Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
It's a paycheck
The people (doers) are great people to work with.
cons:
Understaffed
long hours
big expectations and workload because they run lean
no bonus but George can have one
Executive and senior management make poor decisions
Good talent is often walking out the door
Good talent is often let go and replaced with offshore resources
Not valued as an employee
Basically the walmart of pharmaceuticals

review_title: Hard work but completely fufilled by helping others!
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The best part of working at Express Scripts is the common demoninator in all of the work you do everyday results in helping people get their medications. Its an innovative culture that requires you to collaborate and learn everyday with your team and internal partners. There is a lot of room for advancement as the company continues to grow and they foster the growth of their employees who display passion for what they do. They do require a lot of time & hard work of their employees, however, they offer work from home programs within many teams and promote advancement within the organization. Express Scripts offers a very aggressive bonus structure that rewards efforts and outcomes of the entire organization.
cons: Its a world of continuous improvement at Express Scripts and with that comes consistent change and learning. You must have a passion for improvment and change or else it can be overwhelming along with keeping up with healthcare reform. It can all be very demanding!

job_title: Senior Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
New leadership has set a positive vision and tone for the company, from investing in wellness and professional development programs to allowing jeans all summer long (and maybe beyond!). 

Great people. Everyone I've worked with wants to pitch in, shows passion for the company and their job, and is willing to go above and beyond. A driven group of professionals.
cons: The company runs lean - if you're looking for lots of outside consultant help, easy approval to add positions, or lots of warm and fuzzy perks, this isn't the place. If you want to contribute and are willing to work for results - even if it means putting in some weekend and evening hours during peak times - then you'll fit right in.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Liberty Lake, WA
pros: Vacation time is really good, at least on the Legacy Medco side of things.
cons:
Upper management does not care at all about the employees.  Everything is about numbers, to the point where it's detrimental to our customers.  They want attainable numbers, but care nothing for sustainable numbers.  If you have the audacity to speak your mind, even with data backing you up, they are willing to strip as many privileges away from you as they possibly can.

Morale is terrible.  I used to work for Medco, and the company was so much better to its employees, and in turn, to its patients.   Middle management is in a turn over extravaganza, and everything is falling apart.

And the company doesn't seem to care.  It's still all numbers, and if we can't stay up to par, even when they throw barriers in our way to slow us down, then we're obviously just not good enough.

review_title: Former 10 yr Medco/now ESI respected and praised employee to being treated like a pee-on and disposable person.
pros: Great coworkers and good pay
cons: Prior to the buyout, the emphasis of the resolution dept was to de-escalate a caller, make them feel good about the company while understanding plans, policies, sops and then primarily getting them their meds asap.  The new company is mostly concerned about AHT and wanted these callers handled in 5-7 minutes.  Talk about being robotic and not caring about the patient on the other end of the phone.  There used to be a concern about the average handle time, but not too much, as the caller / patient was important.  Supervisors also kept threatening to fire people if the AHT was not under control.  It was extremely stressful and very hard working under such awful conditions.

job_title: Senior Account Executive in Bloomington, MN
pros: Good pay, PTO, Benefits, work from home.
cons: Plan on working 24/7.  Meetings consume days at all hours due to sites nationwide in different time zones.  Too many clients to manage.  With ESI and Medco merger company is too big.  Areas account management rely on show no accountability, deadlines are missed.  A lot of barriers and inefficient processes so to accomplish something that should be quick and easy takes weeks many times months.  Good pay is not worth sacrificing your life and you and your family suffer.  Life is too short.

job_title: Patient Care Advocate/SFO in Lake Mary, FL
pros: Great Benefits, Pay is Decent NOT great!
cons: PTO is almost impossible to be approved, Mandatory Overtime given at an hours notice, NO mutualrespect among departments,micromanaged, Very Busy dealing with extremely ill pts and we are expected to provide world class customer service in 375 seconds while explaining to someone they have a $1,000.00 co pay etc.... for a month supply of drugs..... this is unprofessional!

pros: Pay and benefits are good.  Opportunities for advancement in leadership exist if you have the energy, are willing to put yourself above your employees, and have the cunning to thrive in a highly political shark tank.  It's a great company for those with the right personality and life situation.
cons: Terrible for people with families and/or expectations outside work.  Company doesn't seem to value its employees.  Hard work is rewarded with more work.  Company does not celebrate successes.  Shareholders will always be taken care of before employees.  Disrespectful behavior by (some) executives is tolerated and seemingly encouraged.  Performance management methodology creates too much competition between employees and shifts emphasis from actual contributions to arbitrary actions like "visibility."  Culture of being cheap.  Suboptimal systems and processes abound.

review_title: Merger not as bad as I anticipated
pros: Great co workers, great benefits,love what I do!!
cons: ESI more demanding and they watch your every move,must be able to account for every moment in idle time. Makes it more stressful, but also makes us accountable. If we do our jobs we don't have to worry about job security.Recognition program now in place makes it nearly impossible to earn enough reward perk points to even redeem your reward points to get anything worth the wait. Miss the wow program. Raise wasnt as good as last year even though I did better overall than past years. Upper management keeps changing things just as we get adapted to it.

review_title: Where are the Ethics, abuse of positional power at the expense of the employees?
pros: There are no "pros" for employees who are expected to contribute to the inflated compensation packages of high level executives who are more focused on managing their personal careers and competing with other CEOs compensation packages rather than truly managing the operation or serving the customers. Corporate greed clouds their minds.
cons: Full-time, dedicated & loyal employees pay the price in reductions & job eliminations while top executives cash in tens of millions. Top executives don't consider the welfare of the employees or patients. They only mention patients when they have an audience because their first priority is consumed with manipulating Wall Street for their own advancement.

review_title: Good benefits just favorite and nepotism making workplace environment toxic
pros: 20 PTOs + 6 holidays to start and get more after certain years of service, but starting 2020 they increase holidays to 8 but cap PTO to 23 max unless you are executive, then you can have > 23 PTOs. Casual environment (jeans). In Finance, If you are lucky to have a nice boss that just cares about getting things done instead of babysitting your attendance, you will have WFH option and flexibility. In Finance, Pay raise annually is about 3% or more. Some nice and knowledgeable people.
cons: Favoritism and nepotism strongly exists in some Finance sub-organization despite lots of efforts touting inclusion, diversity and all positive things. Minority females don’t get fair promotions and recognition although they put in as much or even more effort and accomplishments than their white males coworkers.

review_title: Great experience, poor work life balance
pros: There is plenty of opportunity to learn and grow in this fast paced organization. I cannot argue with the experience I was given and the ability to advance and learn.
cons: Unfortunately, the expectations on goals and objectives execution and unrealistic commitments to Wall Street and internally contribute to a poor work-life balance. Senior leadership (VP and above) are out of touch of the real work that is required and are not compassionate about such work. Positive reinforcement and award are limited but the pay is extremely competitive. That is the only thing that kept me there until I finally decided to move on.

review_title: Input pharmacy technician for mailorder company
pros: Don't need to speak to the customers, you get to sit all day long, you get to wear headphones and listen to your music.
cons: The downside is the pay is not very good. I have been in many pharmacy settings and this by far has been the lowest paying position I have held. When it was time for a raise, I only received a 13 cent raise after working there for one and a half years. There's no "teamwork" even though they have teams, you can not talk to each other without getting in trouble. I feel like I'm back in grade school working there.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
We did get bonuses last year, we will probably not get those again
I like what I do each day. 
Work life balance is not a problem for me
The facilities are newish and pretty
cons:
Management is a mess.  No reviews, one on one meetings are constantly pushed back or cancelled outright, feedback is hard to come by.
Lay-offs always seem right around the corner. 
Overall business model is sketchy and it seems like earnings are going to keep falling, but the executives will always get their money. 
The merger with Medco was a mistake.
Employees are numbers to management; I've been referred to as a 'budget item"
Use of forced ranking is dehumanizing

review_title: Being All In is one big joke
pros: The check clears every week. Good 401k match
cons: Patients health and safety do not matter it's all about the production numbers. The integration is still nowhere close to be completed in the pharmacies. People are forced to work in the dark with no heat in December. Senior management doesn't care about employees. Despite the ethical objections and addictive nature of gambling, they want you to be "all in" for patients. Well, that is if the patient can be handled in less than 6 minutes- after that they're just wasting resources. Cost of health benefits is through the roof. Outdated system that constantly freezes up. A call center in Manila where English is obviously not spoken well ( hey let's be all in for our elderly patients by forcing them to talk to "Mike" from Manila in broken English)

pros: work at home program when they aren't threatening to bring you back in everyday.
cons:
everything
idk when it became a competition to work. they expect you to complete tasks that are just unable to be done. the only way they can be done is if you are a favorite and to be a favorite you have to suck up to no end or work 24/7. they consistently are changing the way your supposed to do things. make up rules are they go.. then when you get a quality its your fault because you didn't do it right. Not a place for families or with a family growing. You have to contact three source to call out.  you may get a point but no one else will. it comes down to favoritism. And how you can bring up your numbers. everyday is a threat. Different supervisor every 6 months - 1 year. Doesn't help.

pros: It's a job with benefits,  I'm only staying until I find better . The pay is better than most pharmacies.
cons: Over worked,  high school environment, favoritism

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Great way to learn to work in a very fast-paced, demanding environment. There are lots of opportunities, lots of different areas to learn.
cons: If you live in STL, your WFH options can be almost zero. St. Louis traffic can be a lot like LA traffic, so hour-long or more commutes are common depending on where you live. It'd be more efficient timewise to allow more flexibility. I think it'd improve morale a lot, too. Workload is also very unevenly distributed within depts. I don't know if this is human nature, but for those who have a heavier workload than everyone around them can be disheartening. The bureacracy in some departments is also ridiculous. It can take months sometimes to get something done that could've been accomplished in a matter of hours.

review_title: Self-absorbed mgmt while employees tirelessly work for customers
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Bloomington, MN
pros:
Great pay and bonuses.
The people in the trenches trying to help the customers are hard working and passionate.
cons:
Mgmt spends it's time trying to figure out how to increase their own pay, cut employee costs, and buy another company.
Work life balance is a buzz word only. For a company that prints money the benefits (outside of pay) are weak. Just 6 holidays? Company tries to grow thru acquisition instead of improving employees and processes. Loyalty is purchased so workers burn out or get frustrated or both. Contractors are abused.

pros: Only thing that would be remotely close to a pro is that you get paid weekly, and you'll have a 40 hour per week schedule.
cons: Besides the basic devaluing of the employees that are "overpaid" for there services. The constant micromanaging from management, the unwillingness to recognize and provide a safe environment for the employees to work mentally and physically, the harassing tactics that occur when an employee has a complaint about the work environment and/or management, the heavy load of work that is enforcement with no incentive except the basic concept being provided with employment. There are many clients contracted with the company that REQUIRE proper training that is NOT provided by management. When the negative comes back from the client, only the customer service department is reprimanded. There is no work/life balance, there is not one perk, there is no happiness from the existence called working for Express Scripts.

review_title: Worst job ever in my 25 years of nursing
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Los Angeles, CA
pros: Autonomous position,  basically set your own hours and schedule.  Not stuck in a building all day.  Meet great and inspiring patients!!
cons: Managers with no experience in this particular field of nursing.  Absolutely no support from management of any kind.  Quick to fault without the benefit of the whole picture.  No positive feedback whatsoever.  Extreme home/work imbalance and low pay.  Pts/customer needs are not a priority in this company.  Before Express Scripts took over,  we were MedCo/Accredo.  Patient safety and satisfaction was the number one priority.  Unfortunately the same can't be said for Express Scripts. The values of the company are not focused on their primary asset,  the patient. I'm ashamed to admit to any kind of association with this company.

pros: Great Benefits, PTO, Health Care, Pay is about average if not in IT.    Typically great management at the middle level.  Some work from home, flex schedule, and overall a very Professional environment as long as your not in the call center.
cons: Awful development opportunities.  No training - consistently baptism by fire at ESI.  Though the middle management level seems to be of high quality, the upper management; typically the Director and Sr. Director level leaders are really poor.  There is a major disconnect there.  Sr Leadership to include VP's and up will give one message, that's not followed by upper management, but that's then followed by middle management.  Depending on where you will work in this company and your leadership will completely change the Pros and Cons with this company.  Overall poor work/life balance but again it all depends on where you'll work.

pros: Express Scripts always does what is right for our patients and clients. They cultivate a family atmosphere and care about us as employees. We are compensated well when our results are good. It is really great working for a company that is aligned with our customers and I feel like I am able to make an significant impact everyday. I am empowered to do what is right ethically and feel supported by Express Scripts to create positive change. Our Senior Staff team is down to earth and approachable.
cons: It is a fast paced environment and we are always evolving to meet the needs of our customers. Our customers demand a lot from us because they are responsible for managing costs for their patients. Tough job but equally rewarding.

review_title: Pay was good, raises bad, overall good place to work
job_title: Pharmacy Technician/Data Entry Clerk in Albuquerque, NM
pros:
I got moved up after only 2 months of working to a specialty department faxing doctors and doing collections. 
We were allowed to listen to music while working.
Flexible schedule, after a few weeks of training I was allowed to pick my own schedule. 
Good benefits.
cons:
Horribly repetitive processing 40 prescriptions an hour, but that's typical production environment.
Only got a 10 cent raise after 9 months, and I was one of their top performers, but the pay was still good for the work.
If you can't work full time for any reason, find another job. They are not flexible on how many hours one works.
Everything was really disorganized, one prescription would hit several places around the country or sometimes sit in a queue for weeks at a time.

pros: Great people,good manager for my department, option to work from home.
cons: Since the merger the work is non stop I am doing the job of 4 people! Teammates are taking anti anxiety meds just to log on in the morning.. stress levels are extremely high. Tat time is nearlt impodsible due to the amount of work!! We are considered numbers,no longer people. The ESI way is robotic and non personalable. From calls to emails everything is becoming scripted, although there isnt a script! Upper managmenr has tied the hands iof the dept manger. Employees with long term "Medco tenure" are quitting left and right. ESI needs to re-evaulate keep the some of the Medco core values, they were working!!  Life became miserable after the merger.

pros: Work from home option, pay is decent, good benefits
cons: On the outside, this looks like a great place to work, progressive, good benefits, the appearance of a work/life balance and it's a good facade. But the truth is everyone is overworked, 45 hours a week is a considered bare minimum, I worked closer to 50-60.  Organization is there, but it feels like no one knows what anyone else does.  Training is lacking and when I mentioned that, I was told I should just know what to do.  This would cost and the only concern is adding to the black.  That's is great, but I'm more of quality first, money second kind of person.  If your not, this may be just the ticket for you.

review_title: “Not the same as Medco Health Solutions AKA "Merck Medco or Paid Prescriptions" ”
job_title: Client Service Specialist in Las Vegas, NV
pros: There are pockets of people with deep healthcare knowledge trying to do the right thing for the customer/client.The pay & benefits are okay, less than other customer service jobs in the same field.
cons: This company only looks for cost savings and does not handle situations logically. I previously worked for Medco Health Solutions before Express Scripts purchased them and Medco paid a much higher salary, had better benefits and was more concerned with getting things handle properly as opposed to looking out for profits first then the patient. Unrealistic expectations, long hours leading to eventually burn out & illness.

pros: Express Scripts offers great benefits and the management has an open door policy. I possessed an entry level position when I started and was still able to speak to one of our senior directors just by sending them an email. I was able to gain the experience that was needed in order to move forward on my career path,
cons: Every company has its cons, my comment on the cons would be how difficult it is to progress within the company. They do promote from within but there are not many positions that are open and it takes time for one to become available. In addition, it is often hard to get days off when needed, there is no "sick time" granted unless you use your personal paid time off or FMLA. Overall I believe Express Scripts to be a great company to work for!

pros: Good benefits - that's about it. The cafeteria is pretty good. Health insurance is OK, and the 401K match is average.
cons:
Some of the most immature and unqualified managers/directors I have ever worked with. I have no idea how these people got to their positions - maybe there were no other choices? My current manager is petty, vindictive, and an absolute nightmare. It's a crazy thought, but I like to learn from my manager. I've had great managers at other companies who improved my skill set, took an active interest in my career, and mentored me. My manager at ESI puts me down, sets a tone of pervasive negativity, and frankly, has taught me everything I don't want to be as a manager.

I've heard other departments/teams may be better, but the risk you take of getting a manager like mine at ESI is too great. Don't do it. If you don't believe me, just take a look at the amount of employee turnover they have.

review_title: I made the right decision in spite of the Glassdoor rating.
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros:
- Culture is moving in the right direction. I attribute this to having a new CEO and CIO.
- Although dependent on the manager you report to, excellent work/life balance.
- Highly technological company and moving to position us as a true technology company.
- Compensation is better than what I have seen/experienced at other companies.
- I can finally feel good about utilizing my skills for a company with a noble objective.
- Upper management doesn't play the "need to know game". Ask a question and you get a straight answer even if you may not like the answer.
cons: To be honest, I do not have any cons at this point. Granted, I have only been at Express Scripts for a short time, but from what I gather, Express Script's ideals and goals are aligned with my own ideals and goals.

pros:
- Monday through Friday schedule
- Generous vacation
cons:
- Work/life balance
- Constant overtime due to always being behind
- Poor management
- Unrealistic expectations
- Treated as a number 
- High stress 
- Low pay 

Quite possibly the worst job I have ever had. It's a call center job which already sucks but the poor management made it worse. While I did like the managers as people they were always making choices that negatively affected patients/customers which made them understandably upset but very difficult to deal with. Their poor decisions always caused employees to be in overtime then management blamed the employees for their shortcomings. Lastly it is really hard to advance. Partly because of high turnover which provided limited opportunities but several people had been promised promotions or new duties that could lead to promotions that regularly fell through. I wouldn't recommend this job to anyone.

review_title: Sweatshop full of suck ups and brown nosers
job_title: Systems Administrator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: ESI is in a great industry, they have very nice facilities. ESPP was very good, pay and benefits were adequate.
cons: Before I started, a friend told me that he had heard the ESI was a sweat shop. After working there I would totally agree. Poorly architected solutions resulted in many hours of extra off hours support weekly. 3 years in, and I was moved to a different group and not honestly told what my job duties would be. I found out that they expected me to to spend 80% of my time supporting legacy technologies that I made a conscience effort 10 years earlier to move away from. Mgr said, if you are going to work at ESI, this is what you are going to do - end of discussion. HR was powerless to do anything to help. In addition, I found many employees to be suck ups and brown nosers, playing the game to gain favor of mgmt without regard to how they treat others.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Las Vegas, NV
pros: As  Medco they were a great place to work.  Really treated  the employees  well.  Good wages  as long as  you  were with  Union.   Quarterly  bonuses  once in a while.   buffet style lunches  brought in  from  Three Squares.  Employee  recognition  held  in  cafeteria with  flavored  punch and  snacks provided  free.  Christmas  parties  held at   select  casinos   but  employees  had to  buy tickets and pay for  own drinks no matter what you drank.
cons: All the parties and extras   stopped   once  Medco became  Express Scripts.  Everything  went  down hill to rock bottom.

pros: Good Salary, Good Benefits, Strong sense of unity, good value prop,  most people who work  for Express Scripts are highly skilled, and  want to do well. Strong mid level leadership.
cons: Silo-ed approach to problem solving, Grown too big to adequately sustain strong customer focus. True concern for member and client experience has taken a back seat to clinical innovation and grabbing for more market share.  There is a "culture of fear". Most employees are afraid to ask, tell of share, and most of the time the person who matters (leadership) is too busy to actively listen.

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Charlotte, NC
pros:
- Some of the staff do care sad that the bad apples take the cake though
- pto 
- GETTING A NEW JOB
cons:
- Micromanaging 
- nit picking little things
-  they offer this thing called vto (voluntary time off) which is where if calls are slow you can choose to take it and go home for the day pay or unpaid the only downfall is most of the time its gone before they send a company wide email out. 
- favortisim
- not much room for advancement
- STUPID BONUS PLAN- Surveys decide your bonus they have a thing called PAD you get 15 cent each opportunity each account can have 1-5 if you take 100 calls and get 200 points * 0.15 your bonus for the pad metric is - $30 yay how awesome NOT and you have to have a 5 survey score and resolve rate of 90% to get a bonus of $150 haha what a joke its not possible to do that. 
- Management seems to be against you and only for themselves
-  pretty much everything

review_title: Worst job I've ever had! RUN!
job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Orlando, FL
pros: Kahoots during orientation after that it went downhill fast
cons: Patients were the worse. They think they can degrade you and can call you every name in the book. And guess what...you're not allowed to hang up on them no matter how bad they get. Screw the patients. Non stop calls that will cause you to go insane. They expect you to answer the next call within 30 seconds so you cant catch your breath. Metric call center which makes proving customer service difficult. Supervisors who just want you do get on the phones and gossip like high school kids. Short lunch which is only 30 minutes. Doesnt even feel like you sit down. Old phones that constantly breaks down. Doctor offices that try to belittle you. Had a call were this angry lady receptionist called because a botox wasnt delivered. I tracked the package and it showed it was delivered. She then called Express Scripts every name in the book (and rightfully so) then look at the packages and found the Botox in the bottom of the packages.She looked like an idiot after that lol. Screw them too.

review_title: Express Scripts treats employees as expendable tools to be used and replaced as needed
pros: They will hire non-certified pharmacy technicians, so you can gain the knowledge necessary to pass the certification test. Certified technicians are paid a little more. It can be a good entry point into this career field.
cons: Upper management has no respect for the workers. They are very demanding and always want more output, regardless of how well you are performing. Frequently require mandatory overtime, often with just a few hours notice (they do not care how this impacts your family or other obligations). Very little opportunity for advancement, and management plays favorites so if they do not like you personally, it does not matter how qualified you are.

pros: Express Scripts is a large Prescription Benefit Manager (PBM) that is a leader in the industry.  They are very profitable due to streamlining their processes without sacrificing client or member satisfaction.  The infrastructure across the organization seems to be well organized and the corporate culture is professional and employees strive for excellence.
cons: Salaries appear to be slightly lower than industry standards, possibily because corporate center is located in St. Louis, MO.  Response time is sometimes slow, depending on what functional area is involved.  Legal and regulatory questions/issues seem to take a quite a while to to resolve.

review_title: Unbelievably hostile and backward thinking work environment
pros: Roof over my head. keeps the rain off my keyboard and the wind from whistling through my hair.
cons: Medco was tolerable.  ESI is greedy.  6sigma lean, 6s, HR, a complete dissolution of most benefits, no pay increases in last 7 years.  Don't even try to have a life or go to school.  They won't allow schedule changes for it.  If you are a robot and enjoy a lack of pay increases, working the hours they want you to work, and continually striving to meet constantly increasing rates with no benefit to yourself out of FEAR they'll fire you than this is your dream job.  If you like contributing years of quality improvement and leadership with absolutely no recognition for your contributions, sign up!  Just don't punch out of work 1 second early on accident before a holiday...they'll take your pay for that holiday like a thief.

pros: You have a job to pay bills.
cons: The health coverage is terrible. The Pharmacy tech and pharmacy clerks have not received a raise in years and I mean years. They will tell you they are negotiating contracts ........but it will take you years to see the pay. The head of the company is cheap. He doesn't want to provide good health coverage and raise pay. They work you like a slave. You may as well stay away from this hell hole. The worst job I ever worked. You will stand all day long on hard concrete with mats under your feet. Mind you the mats where provided not too long ago. They didn't always have them, which shows they didn't care about  your feet, back problems which could arise. This company and all the management stink.

job_title: Senior Pharmacy Technician in Tempe, AZ
pros: Benefits begin at start date
cons: The only way to be successful at this company is to have your head up your supervisor, manager, and/or directors a$s.  Don't be fooled with the "Express Way Values".. there is unprinted exceptions that unknowingly apply to you.  Know your leader - Two-thirds gossip and spread rumors worse than your average magazine.  If you haven't learned yet, 'he said' 'she said' bullsh*t is a great way to write you up or get you fired.  If you liked elementary school; this is the place for you!

review_title: I worked for HealthBridge, a subsidary of Express Scripts and the culture and Supervisors needs to be developed
job_title: Data Entry Pharmacy Technician in Maryland Heights, MO
pros: The benefit packages are great. The tuition reimbursement program really helped me get through undergrad.
cons: No development or training for Leads and Supervisors once promoted.  It is good that Healthbridge promotes from within, but the team knows more than the Supervisor's when they hit the floor. It is very fast paced and Supervisor's have to learn programs on their own with little assistance from upper management.

review_title: A downward spiral in every way
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: 401k match and employee stock purchasing plan are above average. Depending on which department you work in, you may have remote access and the ability to work from home. I have made some wonderful friends in my time with ESI and I have a great team that I work with.
cons:
ESI is a culture of passing the buck, going for the cheapest solution even if it isn't the right solution, expecting 110% devotion to your job above all else and allowing favoritism to determine your advancement. 

There is no accountability unless you are low man on the totem pole, in which case everything is your fault and you are expected to fix everything even when you aren't provided the systems or permissions to do so. 

Team members are constantly pitted against each other due to how reviews are done where someone has to be rated below threshold even when all team members have performed well.

The entire merger has been a disaster. Migrating clients to a system that isn't supported well and doesn't offer anywhere close to the flexibility of our old system has made for frustration and animosity between Legacy Medco employees and Legacy ESI employees. Customers are less than happy with all of it as well, but upper management continues to act like this merger has been perfect and anyone who says differently is labeled as not being a team player and has their lives made very difficult.

Every person I work with is expected to do what equates to at least 2 people's jobs (except the "favorites" who get away with doing next to nothing and spending large portions of their day BS-ing with management). Pay does not reflect the added responsibilities. Extended hours are just expected for salaried employees including weekends, holidays and even when they are technically on vacation or on PTO. For hourly employees, overtime is not allowed (in my area), yet all work is still expected to be done in the allotted 40 hours when realistically there is 50 or more hours of work per week assigned. Hourly employees are bullied about even minutes of OT. Stress levels are ridiculous and I personally know of 4 co-workers who have gone on either anti-depressants or anti-anxiety medications within the last year because of ESI.

When you somehow manage to succeed and meet the ridiculous expectations, you are not rewarded or promoted...you are given more work and maybe an "atta boy" or "atta girl" if you are lucky. If you complain about any of the workload, you are none too subtly told that you are replaceable and that you should be grateful you even have a job. (references to the Legacy Medco employees who have been let go are not uncommon when complaints are voiced)

Speaking of which, the constant threat of being "laid off" if you don't kill yourself to meet the unreasonable expectations has fostered a community that lives in fear of making a mistake or saying even the smallest of things that can be taken as not toeing the company line. Since nobody wants their name attached to even the smallest mistake, nobody is willing to take any responsibility for anything, make any decisions that may elicit change of any kind or speak up when they see something being done wrong. Finger pointing, passing the buck and throwing your co-workers under the bus has almost become company policy when something goes wrong.

The pathetic attempts by ESI to show they appreciate their employees are just that...pathetic. I don't want free cupcakes or donuts every other month during a 2 hour window where you have to go down to the lunchroom area and wait in line to get said cupcake. I don't want a $1 store keychain flashlight that stops working within days. I don't want another cheap backpack or coffee mug with ESI blazoned all over it. I don't care that you dedicate a day each month to wearing our favorite sports team's shirt. that doesn't tell me ESI appreciates me. It tells me that they have no clue about what it means to really appreciate their employees or show them even the slightest respect. It is borderline insulting as I feel it treats me like a small child who can be distracted away from all of the horrible mess that ESI has become by a sugary treat or cheap item thrown my way every now and again. 

Seeing the huge bonuses that George Paz has gotten the last few years as well as his overall compensation package makes me feel sick. During that same time period I have been told "no bonuses this year because of the merger", "we can only offer up to a 3% raise because according to market research, we've been overpaying our employees and this should bring salaries back in line with the average" and "our budget can't support promoting anyone in the department". Really? Because Mr.Paz and upper management don't seem to have trouble finding it in the budget to give themselves pay raises and bonuses every year. Why is it only us peons that have to give up compensation during a merger or budget crunch? Oh. that's right. It's because we don't matter to upper management. We are that gunk stuck to the bottom of their shoe that they can't be bothered to scrape off, but certainly don't acknowledge as anything worthwhile.

And on the subject of Mr.Paz, I really do not care for the emails he sends out telling us how we should be voting on certain issues when they come up on the ballot or to call our Congressman or State Legislators and tell them to vote a certain way on issues. Just because that ballot item may be good for ESI, that doesn't mean that it is good for me and my family or reflect my own personal beliefs. Stop trying to push me to vote in a certain way! 

There is no such thing as a work/life balance at ESI. If you attempt to maintain a life outside of your job, you are quickly relegated to the sidelines and you have no hope of ever advancing or being taken seriously.

review_title: Treat very capable employees with disrespect based on management goals to get ahead and receive big bonuses to cut staff
pros: Decent benefits.  Nice building to work in.  Nice co-workers
cons: The cost of living in St. Louis is much lower than many other sites, therefore salaries are low for higher cost of living cities.  No training opportunities unless you are willing to do it on your own time and pay for it yourself. Unreasonable deadlines and no regard for work/life balance.

review_title: Depends on the department your in
job_title: Senior Quality Assurance Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I loved the work that I did at express scripts.  I did system testing for drugs.  The work was challenging and very intetesting.  Its a good way to get into healthcare because they have so many different departments and they actually train you to do the work.
cons: I found that the team I was on didnt want to share the knowledge.  I had a hard time getting my information.  The communication was very bad.  To many clicks.  Team Members who have been there the longest think they run it.   All departments are not like that, but many there are.

review_title: Why People Don't Like Working at Express Scripts
job_title: Senior IT Engineer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: A lot of good people sprinkled throughout.  A very nice bonus program and an excellent 401k (6% company match).
cons:
I spent nearly a decade working for Express Scripts, which made it a very difficult decision when I recently left the company.  For most of those years, things weren't bad (although there were certainly were frustrations).  However, the culture has become very, very sour after the Medco merger 2 years ago, and good people have been leaving in droves ever since.

The internal politics at the company have gotten so thick that it is nearly impossible to get anything done.  On one hand, you have the legacy ESI folks, many of whom have grown up with the company.  On the other hand, you have the legacy Medco folks who remain resentful that their company got bought, and who seem to have an unhealthy distrust for anything coming out of St. Louis.  The two companies continue to operate under the ESI umbrella, and they both have some representation in leadership.  The sad part is, that the two sides don't cooperate at all, and tend to sabotage each other at every opportunity.  Cooperation is rare, and senior leadership doesn't force either side to compromise or take direction.

If you come up with a better way of doing things at ESI, it will be fully your responsibility to convince *everyone* in the east and the west that the change needs to happen. Unfortunately, this is an impossible task due to the amount of red tape involved, and the ongoing divide between the legacy companies. From an IT perspective, this means that their technology stack is completely antiquated, and there is little hope of moving the company forward.  This also leads to a situation where nearly everyone believes that the company doesn't value them at all, and it has become incredibly difficult to do a good job and make things better, even if you want to. This unfortunately leads to a situation where very few people work hard at all, and almost nothing ever gets done.

All of this frustration has led to an environment where a sense of discontent permeates through the hallways. Behind closed doors, most employees have very little respect for the company or for senior leadership, and things seem to only be getting worse. When surrounded by such negativity day after day, it really starts to affect your mood and outlook, even when you aren't working. To make matters worse, many talented people have already left the company, and because of a sour reputation around town, replacing them with talented individuals has become nearly impossible.  

From a culture perspective, there is virtually none at ESI.  Very few people get together outside of the office, and the only company get-togethers are formulaic employee-only lunches (one in the winter, one in the summer), where drinking is prohibited and families aren't invited. The St. Louis offices are in a terrible part of town, and most people look forward to leaving the area as quickly as possible after the work day.

review_title: Good benefits, good hours, cold management, horrible pay for exhausting work.
job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Whitestown, IN
pros: The hours are fair, overtime is encouraged and the benefits are great.
cons: The pay is awful for pharmacy techs, considering the amount of work they are expected to perform. Instead of being treated as the backbone of the operation, techs are treated as expendable robots.Techs with specialized roles are expected to perform in leadership roles with no extra compensation. Trainers, expeditors receive no raise to kill themselves, sometimes without necessary resources to do their jobs effectively. They sign up for these roles, hoping that they will get a promotion one day, but there are rarely any opportunities for advancement.

pros:
-flexible dress code at Franklin Lakes Office
-good pay
-work at home opportunities
-New office renovations are modern and fashionable
-Hires a lot of intelligent, hardworking people (I'm surrounded by top-tier minds; that's the truth)
-beautiful campus in franklin lakes (grounds are lush with greenery, massive courtyard that is well landscaped)
-hopeful that tim wentworth turns things around
cons:
-no work life balance
-very lean staffing
-documentation of core systems and software functionality is a joke, must learn everything on your own, rigorous training/SOP's lacking, expertise/knowledge is concentrated in the minds of a few individuals making learning difficult
-management makes major decisions without soliciting the feedback of its employees
-quality is no longer emphasized (this is a company that manages prescription benefits for crying out loud); this is a company wide, systemic problem
-constantly on worst places to work lists (takes 1st place, in fact)
-unable to retain top talent because of poor management

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Port Saint Lucie, FL
pros: I have work for several call center in my life and I have to be honest Express Scripts happens to be one of the better companies to work for, the environment is pleasant and the co-workers are friendly. If you're looking for job security Express Scripts is a good place to start you don't have to worry about being laid off during off season. They have (VTO)  volunteer time off you can choose to use if you like. They have excellent benefits and they encourage their employees to continue their education they're  willing to accommodate work schedule for your continual education.
cons: If you're looking for a permanent shift don't expect to have one with Express Scripts it's constantly changing they have shift bids and you never know what schedule you will end up with. The pay could be a lot better for the amount of work you are doing.

job_title: Prior Authorization Advocate in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Ppl will always be in need of medication (job security), if you put your trust in a job. Benefits good, 401k, school reimbursement
cons: Management is a joke. We just had 7 Supervisor leave the department/company within a 4 month time frame. That does not help moral. Now we have new supervisors that do not know anything. They're more like drones. Communication is lacking. We just had a shift bid in April and now have a new bid that will take affect oct. 23. In this bid we were not given our ranking, nor was our supervisors, because in the April shift bid agents with terrible stats were given great schedules and questions were asked, but no answer. I suppose we are just a # to esi. Modern day slaves. Work/life balance is a joke. When too many agents try  to get out of the department at once, they put an off the books freeze on the department. One supervisor was fired for releasing this information. Nonetheless, don't trust man. My hope is in Jehovah. This battle belongs to Him.

review_title: Prepare to hurry up and wait
job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Saint Marys, GA
pros: Truly superb management and resources team. The training facilitators I began my career with were still available to be used as a resource even months after graduating from training. There is also a great team of diversifed individuals that work really hard at being employee and family centric. Full-benefits.
cons: Communication about changes is very inconsistent. There is a lot of playing around with different skills in order to maximize the money coming in vs. the money going out that they are paying their employees. Compared to other large corporations, their entry-level customer service position pay is very low. Corporation as a whole is not employee centric. Career growth is talked about a lot, but is a lot more difficult to attain than they allude to.

pros: Express Scripts is a large company that has a good future in the PBM industry; is not likely to be bought by another company, and will continue to grow and prosper leading to general job stability.
cons: I originally worked for Medco Health, which was acquired by Express Scripts in April 2012.  The Medco culture was one of innovation, quality and reliability, as well as improving processes and reducing overall costs.  Express Scripts appeared - during the year I worked as an ESI employee - to be focused more on reducing overall costs.  The departments do not work as well with one another as what we had at Medco, so there is always some strife and stress to deal with.

review_title: The beginning was great, until profit, Wall Street and mergers were all ESI cared about.
job_title: Senior Account Executive in Orlando, FL
pros: There are a lot of very smart and educated people at ESI who want to work together and make a difference.
cons: Once management changed, the expectation was that management required you to work around the clock.  You weren't allowed to voice your opinion or collaborate any longer.  Management really just cared about the bottom line.  Even after an employee survey, they pretended to care because the survey showed what everyone though, however, that didn't last long.  The focus was no longer about collaborating and working together to help our clients.  It was all about how much money we could show to Wall Street and because ESI was the biggest, they didn't care anymore about losing clients and doing the right thing.

pros: Absolutely none . The only pro is that they are constantly hiring , which is also a con in my opinion .
cons: After being employed with Express Scripts for over a year the best advice that I can put out there is to simply not work for them . Imagine every negative aspect of a job all in one . Everything from favoritism to poor management and beyond keeps this place at the very bottom of my list of bad job experiences . I would rather work at Amazon fufilment as a seasonal employee than work for Express Scripts in Whitestown . It's a truly horrible job and I say that with hopes that no one watses there engery there .

review_title: Total consuming of all aspects of your life.
pros: The pay rate is high for the field. Good, affordable benefits package.
cons: I thought a four day work week would give me more time for actual life, not the case. We work 11 and 12 hour shift more than 10 hour shifts. The pay is nice, but I never have the time or energy to enjoy anything. Micro-managed beyond necessary, HIGH turn-over, ask so much from the employees, but don't give much in return. No praise for a job well done, but over kill if a mistake is made. Not enough attention paid to the employees heath.....the environment is full of pill dust. I've never had any respiratory issues in my life. After one yr + of working here I now have a nagging cough and frequent sinus/respiratory infections. I'm not the only one.

review_title: Get your experience and get out!
pros:
1. The amount and type of work that you are trusted with is enormous which lets you gain experience at a rapid pace.

2. Paid time off accrual is pretty healthy.

3.  Rise through lower levels of management can be quite rapid.
cons:
1. Salaries are a joke.  Make sure you negotiate well when you join because you will rarely get a promotion raise over 10%.

2. Senior management is all about CYA and they will point fingers and dump you in a heartbeat if they feel that their job is threatened by poor performance.

3.  Fire drills are the norm.  The importance of particular projects always shifts and things rarely get done according to plan.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The teams at Express Scripts are highly collaborative, and the executive leadership has done a tremendous job empowering mid-level managers to make strategic decisions that move their individual departments -- and therefore the company -- forward. Employees are encouraged to stretch themselves, take smart risks, and think beyond their individual role. There are few other opportunities across corporate America where an individual can do such meaningful work for such a major company in such a newsworthy industry.
cons: Express Scripts may not be the best organization for individuals who are uncomfortable in a dynamic, ever-changing environment. There is rarely a standard operating procedure for the important work done here. You must be OK with embracing ambiguity, and building something new.

review_title: It really is up to you
job_title: Senior Management in Saint Louis, MO
pros: This company has certainly evolved and changed.  What has stayed consistent is the management attention to the core values.  The values really do drive the company initiatives.  While delivering work product is essential, there is equal emphasis on how you work with others to get the job done.  Most recently there has been a renewed interest in development and investing in the talent on board; that is quite refreshing.
cons: I don't believe what I will say is necessarily a 'con' but it is certainly a reality in this company.  This is a high performance environment.  Which means you are measured and expected to deliver.  There is rarely a 40h week because there is competition - and reward - for delivering a high quality product.

job_title: Senior Business Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I've been here a long time (15+ years) through many different positions, departments, and management. Like any corporate America job, it has been a roller coaster of both wonderful times, and awful times. The pros in my current position are the flexibility and fantastic co-workers. My boss is amazing, as is his boss.
cons: I am not sure if I drank the koolaid for so many years or if I was never exposed to the shady side of Express Scripts. I once firmly believed in what we did and felt really good about my work that helped support our patients and this company. Over the past year I've been exposed to a new side that (what I feel) does not have our patient's best interest in mind. It makes me not like what I do anymore.

review_title: I hated the job. It truly is a modern day sweat shop.
job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Saint Marys, GA
pros: Medco acquisition. Great benefits. Set schedule. No dress code.
cons: Very sedentary job. Customers were not happy most of the time because meds weren't shipped when they were supposed to. Very stressful. I've read all the reviews and I'm not surprised that employees to meds to be able to function at work.  Lots of change.  Every  week there was a new way of doing things. Mostly chaos because of the merger. Low pay and bogus bonus because when you finally got your stats up, they would train you in another area to bring your stats down. Needs to follow more of Medco's policies. They were number one for a reason. They offered great pay and less scripting.

review_title: If I could find another job that paid me more I would leave. Stuck here in agony.
job_title: Pharmacy Benefits Specialist in Mason, OH
pros: Paycheck direct deposited to account on time.
cons:
Tried to get sent to another department with the company, as I am burnt out on the telephones. Seems like they have their favorites when it is time to promote, or recommend for other departments.
Some days no down time in between calls, Feel like you are chained to the phones.
Health benefits are expensive 
Customers are very rude, and irate. 
Lack of work/life balance. Have to call off to get time with family, which is used against you when time for bonuses.
Past 2 1/2yrs have never had a bonus. Each time I would have made it, cross-trained on another system so start all over with quality and etc.

pros: Company has a strong mission statement and develops concepts that would be beneficial to their clients. The corporate sites are well maintained.
cons: Long work hour shifts (including weekends) for months at a time with no compensation or finishing date provided; forced rating review system based on popularity with senior leadership; poor communication and guidance from senior leadership; company reliance on manual processes (notepads for meetings, desktop workstations) instead of more innovation (laptops, automation for high volume data files); fear of retaliation by middle management for expressing alternative ideas for projects; No effective management training for qualities such as people skills; Human Resources does not always assist with resolving employee issues unless threat of legal action

job_title: Senior Manager in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: Working for Express Scripts is an opportunity to contribute positively to making healthcare in America better.  Every day, I have an opportunity to help patients get their medications, and to help make medication more affordable. I have been extremely happy in my job for more than 15 years. The people are great, the compensation is fair, and while sometimes the job is hard and demanding, that's because we have important work to do.  Anything worth doing is not going to be easy.  On the whole, this is a great company and I would recommend working here anytime I am asked.
cons: I would love more opportunities for growth and promotion. But I recognize that is not always possible. That said, Express Scripts has made sure my good work is always recognized and rewarded, even if a promotion isn't possible.

job_title: QA Analyst in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Express Scripts is a great place to work. Hard work is rewarded, and the company is growing and improving patient health while adding cost savings for patients and clients. The opportunity to work from home is nice. Other benefits include good health insurance, 401K, tuition assistance, and a company stock purchasing option for employees. I appreciate the teamwork and camaraderie and look forward to going to work each day. Management is open to suggestions from employees and takes action to improve processes accordingly.
cons: There are not any big cons. The only thing to watch for is that it can be very busy and the workload can get demanding. There is no need to be overwhelmed, though. We work as a team to help each other out. I appreciate the knowledge sharing from fellow employees and supervisors for faster, smarter ways to work.

review_title: Unhappy employees, very dissatisfied clients and constant turmoil pretty much sums up life at Express Scripts
pros: Good 401k with company matching, pretty good benefits, PTO accrues quickly (good luck using it), good bonus potential, nice colleagues from both legacy companies.
cons: OVERWORKED! I haven't worked less than a 60 hour week in over a year. The culture at ESI has become insanely toxic and the morale among staff is at an all time low. In 18 months,15 employees in my immediate department have resigned. That's 15 people out of about 45.....in less than two years!! Management can not and should not be trusted at ESI. They are only looking to save their own jobs, and will do and say anything in order to do so. It's a shame because this company could be great, but I don't see things improving anytime soon. The lack of work/life balance, the constant lay offs and the adversarial culture at ESI can only mean things will get worse.

job_title: Senior Manager in Saint Louis, MO
pros: There has been a slow, but noticeable culture shift at Express Scripts. I started here as an intern in 2010 and have worked my way up to management level. When I began here there was a 'head-down' culture. People did their work (regularly 9-10 hr days) and didn't complain. In the last year that has changed dramatically. There is still an emphasis on performance and you absolutely have to work hard to succeed at Express Scripts, but I can finally say that there IS work-life balance.
cons: You have to work hard. I find it pathetic to place this as a con, but the majority of working professionals in America have no idea what that means and can't stand up to the pressure of a job that demands hard work.

job_title: Patient Care Advocate in Orlando, FL
pros: The best reason to work for ESI is for insurance benefits.  They're not as good as you might expect for a PBM, but if you don't have anything else, it's an improvement.
cons: Lack of growth opportunities.  The job itself lacks challenges, it's just very monotonous.  Probably the worst part is having to defend business practices that are often indefensible, and having to sell patients on a home delivery service knowing that the product doesn't work.

review_title: Worst job I have ever had - unethical behavior coupled with cutthroat business practices.
pros:
Some people were nice to work with in the St. Louis area.
Acceptable cafeteria.
Clean and modern facility.
cons: This company needs a serious wake-up call to get them to clean up their act.  I saw a lot of unethical behavior in the call center - brought on by the demands of management - and would go as far to say that these people are in need of some serious help.  Someone is going to blow the whistle one of these days and it won't be pretty.  Workers are so taxed that the place has become sloppy and there will be serious costs as a result.  Management just keeps covering it up and I am glad that I left before they ruined me.  Get out if you can.  The people in management have no soul and they will try to steal yours.

review_title: It is what you make of it
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: VERY intelligent and dedicated work force, opportunity to move laterally, very clear communication of company performance indicators, commitment and communication of organization core values
cons: It APPEARS that people considered for promotion to Director and above is reserved for (in large part) a predetermined core group.I think the organization has lost some talent as a result. Beware if you expect to "get you foot in the door" and then work your way up. Apply for the job and level you want. Very young executives in very senior roles. Technical skill and intelligence don't always translate strong senior leadership, absent experience.

review_title: A good place to work if you're an executive
pros:
generous PTO package
flexibility in schedule
good place to start as an entry level employee to gain experience
some employees are friendly
cons: The basic motto at Express Scripts is "prosper the management team at all costs", take from the lower level employees (jobs, bonuses, salaries) and give it to the management team. Turnover rate is very high, not just from people quitting but they also fire multitudes (even though the company is very financially successful). Good, hard work is not rewarded but kissing up to the boss certainly is. Morale is low and the demands placed on the employees are extreme. There is a lot of backstabbing and immaturity and employees throwing each other under the bus.

review_title: grass isn't always greener on the other side
pros: paid holidays, benefit package, 401K, basic company needs and preparedness
cons: I applied for the money and in the end, even that wasn't enough. It isn't a really happy place to work. Little sense of community, no real ownership of fault and if you are a patient care advocate you are thrown to the lions for every issue. Supervisors, on more than one occasion, just did not have the answer. With the merging of the companies and all this reform we were hit with calls that were both abusive and intrusive. We couldn't transfer patients to supervisor unless the patient specifically requested to speak to one, in the mean time, we had to sit and listen and mumble with the mute button on. probably trivial but still unlike any place I have ever worked for.

pros: ESI is horrible. If you want to be under paid, be super stressed, don't have a life, feel like you have to rude and love taking Xanax then ESI is the place too be! Turn over rate is high and no suck time 0.30 raises and who ever makes up this organization are straight "*****! They don't know how or what to run a business and communication, micromanaging and no sense rules they have are made for a robot not a human. Please run. Don't apply. They are horrible and management is a joke and won't help you.
cons: Everything all wrong, run don't look back.

pros:
Medco was a great company to work for. They showed their appreciation for their employees through both pay and the WOW program. 
We will see if Express Scripts can continue that
cons: Leadership does not communicate with management in the sites let alone employees, the plan that they are working on to merge the 2 companies. We are now seeing employees being laid off and have no idea who is next or what the overall goal is. This is highly demporalizing to the employees and the atmosphere at work has plummeted as a result. Management is in no position to help the employees through this because they have not been informed either.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Franklin Lakes, NJ
pros: As long as they keep the building in Franklin Lakes, NJ, the location is great if you live in Northern NJ or NY.
cons: When ESI bought Medco, they decided to use most of the Medco systems but keep their processes.  Over the years Medco grew and improved and now ESI has taken them back to the dark ages.  People are over-worked, others are being let go, and many of those who chose to stay have been demoted.  Morale is at an all time low.  Supplying reports to senior management is NOT more important than fixing problems.  Patching problems is NOT more important than getting to the root cause.

pros: To some extent, Express Scripts is a "meritocracy," work hard, get promoted.    ALL the offices are the same size and there are no assigned parking spaces, no matter what level.  This may seem petty, but its an important aspect of the culture. Bonuses can be lucrative based on company performance.
cons: Express Scripts is a very political place to work.  At a certain level, employees spend a significant amount of time managing PERCEPTIONS of themselves and their performance, as opposed to their actual performance and outcomes.

pros: There weren't many pros other than getting a regular paycheck.
cons: It's Express Scripts, so the pharmacy benefits are as terrible as the age-old "Medco" reputation goes. As for the work, there were many false promises without follow through.  There was no training to speak of, everyone was just thrown to the wolves and expected to perform.  Management spends more time eating food in conference rooms than working.  I knew it was not the job for me within the first 3 days, but I stuck it out as long as I could, hoping for those "promises" to come through.

review_title: It was a great company about 6 yes ago ¡
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
PTO
Flexible work schedule
Benefits
Employer match 401k
Employee stock purchase
cons:
Very little work/life balance.

In IT division have to work on call and can be called at any hour day or night, even late night to come into office to reboot or install equipment or troubleshoot.

Sr management doesn't know what direction to take company in.
Hard to believe Sr management, maybe with Tim taking over as CEO things might change.

To many layers of management to get things done.  Puts me in mind of GE management model.

No job security.... Job can be off shored or eliminated at the drop off a hat.

pros: Great benefits, Co workers are usually very nice and easy to become friends with.
cons: Low pay, damming hours, zero communication with management, lots of favoritism, lots of mandatory overtime, under appreciated, expect to only do your job 10% of the day and rest will be spent helping warehouse assistants.

review_title: Horrible to tenured employees they lay off
pros: Work at home was great. Pay was decent.
cons: Just a number. They don't value any of their employees unless they have favorites. Laid off bunch of people to save money but could have repurposed many of us in different internal positions or at least give us the option rather than throwing us out like garbage after hard work and many years in company (some almost ready to retire).

job_title: Senior Account Executive in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Paycheck delivered on time and they are so busy trying to learn new system they forget about managing the people so you have a lot of down time to search for a new job.
cons: Pay is horrible, health benefits are very expensive, the express values are a joke, very inexperienced management.  Culture is to set a policy and then figure out how to side step the policy.  Rating system or force ranking is ridiculous.

review_title: It's all about the money, money, money
pros: Good benefits, Medco employees are wonderful.
cons: I worked for Medco for 11 years then ESI for 3. ESI has an awful environment, no communications between csr's, supervisors, floor manager and managers. Fast pace that does not let up. ESI ask you to do more and more each day but never trains you and expects perfection when we live in an imperfect world.  No forgiveness for small errors just punishment. Work your butt off, get a 'stretch' on evaluation but no raise given. Work hours are inconsistent, you could work 9-5 then work 11-8, then work 5-2. Doesn't matter how many years you have in. ESI is all about the money, while Medco was about the patients and employees.

review_title: The longer you work for this company the more you see its true intent.
pros: If your a favorite of your manager  or you know someone in upper management then your workload and pay rate can increase and you can pretty much cruise while everyone else works.  The compensation is pretty decent and worksites are clean.
cons: If your not part of this favored group, then expect no work life balance, unreasonable expectations and never seeing your family or outside life again. Its always who you know in this company. But honestly this company is all about the bottom dollar, they could care less who gets trampled by the wayside on their mission for profit.

job_title: Benefit Coverage Review Representative in Tampa, FL
pros: There are no Pros to this company. I have never worked at a place that was so insecure of providing their core values that every manger and supervisor in the Tampa call center was not even able to uphold.
cons: This company's work ethics and trust in their employee's  were so unreasonable and devaluing to human beings who just wanted to work to make a decent and honest living.  Management and Supervisors literally walked around like prison guards and wardens which made it so hard for me to feel comfortable and valued in my position I was hired for.

pros: I originally worked for Medco and the company was great and then ESI took over. My coworkers were great to work with, we all helped each other.
cons: once ESI took over the following happened -- we started to lose the resources that we used to fully take care of our escalated members. The company doesn't care about how the member or what the reps taking the phone calls go through because of this.  ESI then started to eliminate all of the old Medco employees and closed down the sites too.  I would not recommend this company to anyone

pros:
• Demonstrable shift in culture - focus on employees is far greater than I've seen since I've been here.
• New employee-centric health programs
• Greater transparency from senior leadership - huge sea change here
• 2016 PRIDE sponsorship - not just "a" corporate sponsor..."the" corporate sponsor. Wow.
• Casual summer. For a seemingly conservative, quiet company - pretty cool
• Continuing to push hard to make the culture and work environment better
cons:
• Sometimes too many cooks in the decision making
• Occasional "old school/traditional" thinking (but that's slowly going away)
• Processes and old platforms hinder (but, those too, are getting blown up)

pros: Fast-paced environment; company serves important purpose; many dedicated, great people; challenging work; generous bonus structure based on performance; fair compensation
cons: Pace of work and demands on individuals spill into weekends, nights, vacations;  burnout not uncommon;  change of direction and leadership is so fast it can be difficult to feel a sense of completion as you jump from one project to another.

pros:
Locations are close to home
Pay is competitive -- but then, we're talking Pharmacy Tech pay, which is at the bottom of the scale, anyway.
cons:
People are not valued for their contributions -- you have look over your shoulder every minute to avoid being stabbed in the back. I was a good employee; I did good work. No one cared. Everyone is expendable. The "Express Way" is nothing but talk. 

They think they are going to have a "high performing workplace" by firing people left and right. The opposite effect is true -- they have to constantly hire and train new people. That includes management. The poor leadership poisons the entire enterprise.

Express Scripts is by far the worst place I've ever worked, and I've been in the workforce for over 30 years. Pay heed to the majority of the reviews on this site if you are thinking of working at ESI; they are absolutely right! DON'T WORK HERE!

pros: The benefits package is slightly above-average relative to the industry.  Annual bonus payouts can be generous based on individual and organizational performance.
cons: Most of the negative feedback I'd like to share revolves around the annual performance evaluation process, which forces the workforce into Stretch (20%), Target (70%) and Threshold (10%) categories.  As a people leader, I was constantly fighting with Sr. Leadership to keep my staff from receiving a Threshold rating, just because Sr. Leadership needed to fill up the Threshold "bucket".  Several years in a row, I was forced to rate certain of my direct reports as Threshold performers, even though I recommended them to receive Target or Stretch ratings.  This system prevents employees from being fairly and accurately evaluated, and leaves employees feeling that, no matter how hard they work, the forced ranking system dictates your performance outcome, not your actual performance.  Every Manager I knew felt the same way.  This totally dysfunctional system breeds an excessive, unnecessary level of competition among colleagues, and others simply lose their desire to do a good job.  For years, I thought ESI represented the culture of modern corporate America, and that any Fortune 100 company would likely hold similar values.  Now that I'm working for another Fortune 100 company, I can say with confidence that ESI is the exception, and that there are still large American corporations willing to put employees first.  ESI is a miserable place to work.

pros: Good hours, weekends off.  Good vacation.
cons: CEO is an accountant.  Patient health is an afterthought to providing medication at the lowest possible price.  Constant pressure and performance reviews, all phone conversations are taped and many are selected for review of words used and questions asked.  Be prepared to take antacids and feel sick every morning on your way to work.  Work/Life Balance would be great with the hours and vacation, but the work is so demeaning and over-scrutinized that the stress and constant attacks on self-respect cut into the balance.  Professional judgment is not respected.  This company offers cut-rate PBM services to clients that don't care about third-rate service.

pros:
I love the job that I do and the work itself. I love the satisfaction of providing the best service I can for my patients. I know my work area very well and enjoy helping other employees if they seek my help. 

401K, good personal/vacation package, free tea and coffee
cons: I do not feel valued for the service and experience I bring to my job. I haven't had a raise in six years. No bonuses. Management makes petty changes constantly, making the overall workplace environment miserable. Teamwork is discouraged. Management chases metrics at the cost of servicing the patient. The only time I hear from management is when there's a problem. I don't receive recognition or reward for the good work I do. Attendance policy is very strict, no flexibility in schedule. The company has the right to cut hours with minimal prior notice. Health insurance policy is expensive and doesn't seem to cover much. Only six paid holidays.

review_title: Almost 5 years at this company and it hasn't changed a bit
pros: Work from home. That is all
cons: Your manager can make or break your expierence. They can also prevent you from getting other roles in the company without you even being aware that they have blocked you. There is a mindless HR dept that will do whatever management says, clearly undermining the purpose of HR. Some depts are extremely overworked while others do nothing on most days. Senior mgmt has no idea and doesn't have a clue how to fix this.

review_title: Good benefits but have your next job lined up when you start...
pros: Great benefit package and salary
cons:
Toxic work environment
Blame is quickly assigned and then suffer from guilty until proven innocent syndrome
Sr Directors and Junior level VPs are promoted through nepotism and 'favorite children' and not so much and leadership ability or experience
Many in leadership positions are incapable or afraid of making decisions without gaining approval first.  This is rightfully so as many have been punished for leading the charge and making good, timely decisions.  Next line leadership is not good about backing subordinate leaders.
The number of employees that remain with the company beyond 3 years or so drops significantly.  You don't see many 'old timers' here and it's not due to their ability.
